story: NewsMeghan Markles Morocco visit amid mystery of countrys missing princessPrincess Lalla Salma, the we of King Mohammed VI, has not been seen in public since the end of  - with rumours re about her ious whereaboutsShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video harry-meghan-arrive-crowds-greet-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs Meghan Markle and Prince Harry spent the day promoting female empowerment in the glorious Moroccan sunshine - the mystery of the missing princess loomed in the background. It has been almost two years since ruler King Mohammed VIs we Princess Lalla Salma was last seen in public. The pair, who met at a party in  and married several years later, are widely rumoured to have orced - but this has never been confirmed by the Palace or members of the royal family. The disappearance of the -year-old princess from public le is said to have become an elephant in the room with Moroccan media reportedly choosing not to make mention of it.  But when Meghan, , and Harry, , meet King Mohammed, , tomorrow, British officials said they had no ideathe VIP visitors would ask after her in spite of their mission to promote gender equality. The focus of the the Duke and Duchesss four-day trip is also the changing social attitudes towards women in the country. Meghan and Harry have already met the couples son Crown Prince Moulay Hassan, , dubbed one of the “richest teenagers in the world”. He shook hands with the pair at the entrance to their royal villa in the grounds of King Mohammeds palace after they stepped off the plane at Casablanca airport onto a red carpet last night. They are staying as “honoured guests of the King” at one of the opulent royal palacesuntil Tuesday. It was believed to be the first official meeting between the British royal family and the future monarch of Morocco.   The King and Princess Lalla Salma also have an -year-old daughter, Princess Lalla Khadija. Princess Lalla Salmas whereabouts have been the subject of much speculation with rumours shes living in exile in the United States. There has also been a suggestion she is in the Greek Island of Kea with her daughter. Netty Leistra, a royal journalist, told Royal Central : “I think Salma had a very hard job trying to be the first visible we of a Moroccan king.There is quite an age gap too. Salma did some good things and of course, gave birth to two children. I always thought she did rather well. I guess thatthe news is correct about the orce, they will give her a nice big house and all the money she needs so that she won’t say anything about it. But I think it is rather sadit is true.” Like Meghan and Harry, the princess is a prominent supporter of womens rights. She also attended Kate Middleton and Prince Williams wedding in .  The Duke and Duchesss visit is focusing on womens empowerment, social entrepreneurship and girls education. Today the couple visited a school boarding house run by Education For All, an organisation for girls aged between  and  from some of the poorest and most remote areas of the country. The Duke and Duchess dropped into a classroom and spoke to some of the girls studying for exams, for whom without the school they would not have the chance to reach their full potential. It is a project transforming attitudes to female education in the Moroccan mountains and something the Duchess of Sussex wanted to visit. A heavily-pregnant Meghan also took part in a Henna ceremony, in which -year-old student Samira decorated the Duchesss hand with a henna flower to celebrate her pregnancy. The henna is tradition in Morocco and a blessing during the seventh month of pregnancy to celebrate the health of mother and baby. This evening, Harry and Meghan were greeted to Rabat residence of British Ambassador Thomas Reilly.  Upon entering the home the Duke and Duchess were given a traditional rosewater greeting and were officially welcomed by the ambassador’s we Leah. Meghan dazzled in a Moroccan inspired kaftan style Dior gown, with Dior clutch bag. At the glittering reception the royal couple mingled with guests from across Moroccan society including young leaders, entrepreneurs, business representatives and influential people from local girls’ education and sport. Meghan discussed the boundaries women face and issued a clarion call to feminists around the world. She said: “Women have to challenge everywhere in the world.” The event was held to highlight the positive dference the guests have made to Moroccan society through their influence and activities. A spokesperson for The Duke and Duchess previously said: Their Royal Highnesses are very much looking forward to the visit and are grateful to their hosts and the British Embassy for arranging such an interesting programme. They are particularly pleased that they will have the opportunity to meet so many young Moroccans over the next few days.

title: curran an injury worry for dundee ahead of hibs clash on friday
story: Craig Curran is Dundee’s major fitness doubt for their Friday night clash with Hibs at Dens Park.The former Dundee United and Ross County striker played at Livingston last weekend but has been nursing a stomach problem since the draw with Kilmarnock a fortnight ago.He hardly trained last week and has been missing again over the past few days.“Craig is very sore, he didn’t train all last week because of a stomach thing,” said boss Jim McIntyre.“He’s going to require a few days to get over it.”If it’s a case of wait and see with Curran, Jim is confident both Andrew Nelson and Andreas Hadenius will make it.Nelson had to come off after netting the equaliser at Livi when he aggrevated ankle and calf problems as he celebrated his goal.And Swede Hadenius was replaced early in the second half at the weekend after picking up a knock.Both, though, have responded to treatment and are expected to be fit for Friday.With four goals since his arrival from Sunderland last month, -year-old Nelson is the man of the moment at Dens.While the manager stresses the young attacker remains a work in progress, he’s been delighted with his performances so far.“Nelson is a goalscorer and I thought his finish at the weekend was excellent,” Jim added.“It looked ashe was stretching but he’s managed to generate it into the corner.“As I’ve said before, he is raw. He still needs a lot of work, working with a partner and when to link and stuff but I’m delighted with his goals contribution so far.”

title: dundee boss mcintyre ready to cross swords with new hibs gaffer heckingbottom
story: Jim McIntyre and Paul Heckingbottom will cross swords for the first time in their managerial careers when Dundee and Hibs clash at Dens tonight.However, while Jim admits to knowing little of his opposite number, his knowledge of the team he’ll be putting out means he’s not expecting too many tactical surprises.Hibs appointed Heckingbottom as the successor to Neil Lennon last week and he kicked off his time in Scotland with an Easter Road win over Hamilton Accies.While, in time, the Dee boss knows his opposite number will put his own stamp on the Hibees, right now he’s not expecting too many drastic tactical changes from the way they lined up under Lennon.“I don’t know him but he got off to a good start and Hibs have good players. It’s going to be a tough game,” said Jim.“He’s got good options as well, you need to be able to handle that.“We know what players he’s got to work with and we know their strengths and weaknesses like we do most of the other squads in the league. It’s about making sure yours are better than theirs on the night, that’s how it is in football.“We are back at home in front of the cameras and want to put on a good performance.”Dundee go into the game boosted by last week’s vital win at Livingston that hauled them out of the bottom two in the top flight for the first time since late August.Again, though, the manager is stressing it’s where the team are at the end of the season that counts.“We could be back down there come Saturdaywe don’t keep it going.“Livingston is gone now and now it’s all about this one.”

title: family pays tribute to dundee guitarist kenny whose music took him all over the world
story: The family of a popular Dundee musician have led tributes to the talented guitarist following his death at the age of .Kenny Day died last weekend having spent the last years of his le living with dementia.A well-known figure on the Dundee music scene, Kenny, from Lochee, played in bands such as The Bad Pennies, Ringer and Sanjo during the s and s.His touring career took him across Scotland and the world where he performed in Germany and New York.Kenny’s son, Kenneth Day Jr, said: “It didn’t matter what it was – everything was a joke to my dad.“I remember his car broke down one night in Germany and he managed to fix the fan belt with women’s tights which were in the car.“A few months later he was still driving around with the tights connected to the fan belt.“He liked the women too. He had all the ladies around him. Even in the care home, he was a charmer.”His daughter, Jackie, , from Fintry, said: “I want people to know how talented he was – music was his le.“He first started out at about age four when he sang on stage with his sister Wilma but he first picked up a guitar at age  and I’m not surehe stole his older brother’s guitar.”Jackie said her father had a wide taste in music, although The Beatles were his favourite and his band Ringer would often cover songs by the Fab Four.Kenneth, , from Menzieshill, said he was inspired to take up guitar by his father.He said: “He would always ask me, ‘which Beatles song are we going to learn this week ’“I play in a band now and took it from my dad. People know my dad – after I put it on Facebook I’ve just had loads of comments with people saying that my dad was like a mentor to them.“Some musicians have been in touch to say my dad taught them how to play.”Kenny’s elder sister, Phyllis Duffin, , from Craigiebank, said his talents went beyond his musical knowledge, adding: “He had learnt six languages from French, Spanish, Urdu to Polish. He was very talented but had no common sense.“He loved going to Campbeltown in the west of Scotland to visit his cousins. I remember phoning through at one point and his cousin telling me he had been chasing their car in a Wombles suit!”Kenny, who was the youngest of four siblings, was diagnosed with dementia in his early s and entered a care home.Jackie said: “He would forget lyrics, it’s like he was fading away. It was a horrible thing to watch.“It was hard for him, he couldn’t drive anymore but he knew what was ahead. He developed a stammer and got frustrated.”Kenneth said: “Dad was a smart man so it was heartbreaking to see him getting ill.“The other week we were all sitting round him and he hadn’t spoken in over two years but then he began blethering and singing in German.“I told my sister that dad was talking and then he recognised Phyllis when she came in.“His music was playing in the hospital room and my sister turned down the stereo.“Dad said, ‘don’t do that again’ – it was braw!”

title: shoppers complain of dundee post office mess as refurbishment is postponed
story: A Broughty Ferry Post Office has had its refurbishment delayed despite complaints of it being littered with “mess”.The Gray Street branch was originally going to close from February  to March  to be given a makeover but residents have now been told the refurbishment has been postponed “indefinitely”.Christine Kenny, from Broughty Ferry, regularly uses the branch.She said: “The condition of the Post Office is a disgrace, with quite a bit of litter around.“There are bags of rubbish dumped in the front shop.”She added: “It was to be refurbished, but when I was in today the assistant mentioned it has been postponed.“The Post Office should have a say about its condition.“Even a brush, cloth or duster wouldn’t go amiss.”Ferry councillor Craig Duncan spoke of the store’s condition, saying: “The refurbishment has been deferred by the postmaster rather than the Post Office. In a way it’s disappointing but it helps in the short term because the Barnhill Post Office remains closed due to fire damage.”He added: “A lot of these matters are down to the postmaster rather than the Post Office to deal with.“I understand the purpose of the refurbishment is to bring these things up to spec and I welcome that and it will happen at some point. It’s a sizeable building and most of the floor space is not being used at the moment.”“We don’t have a timescale for the works to be done but I’ll find out more in the next two to three months.“As soon as I am aware, I will make that public.”In a statement, the Post Office thanked the Tele for bringing the state of the store to their attention and said the postmaster will be contacted regarding the concerns.Postal services at the Barnhill office on Nursery Road have been closed since a fire at the MS News shop on October .The fire caused almost £, worth of damage, closing the store “indefinitely”.The Gray Street shop was closed in January last year until July, so the store could be made more modern.After the last refurbishment, the store had four serving positions on a modern-screened counter, two open-plan positions and a serving point at the retail section.The opening hours also increased by  hours a week, to operate from am-.pm.

title: tom duthie deeiy sos then dundee boss jim mcintyre is the man to call
story: Rather understandably, no one has asked Jim McIntyrehe’s a fan of the hit BBC show DIY SOS.Perhaps we should, becausehe leads Dundee to safety this season he might just be able to lay claim to being the Scottish Premiership’s version of its presenter Nick Knowles.For those lucky enough to watch only football on the box, it’s the one where Knowles and a team of tradesmen step in to help families or groups with building projects they don’t have the knowhow or resources to complete on their own. To add to the drama, it’s done as a race against the clock.And McIntyre is gaining a growing reputation for doing the same with top-flight clubs here.Four-and-a-bit years ago he arrived at Ross County with the Highland outfit seemingly already doomed to relegation.By the end of that season he hadn’t just kept the Staggies up, he’d rebuilt them into a squad that would go on and win silverware in the shape of the  League Cup.After the Dark Blues’ weekend win at Livingston got them out of the bottom two for the first time since the end of August, thanks to goals from new handy men Andrew Nelson and Scott Wright, there are strong signs he can do the same at Dens Park.McIntyre’s reign as Dundee boss started in October when he received an SOS from owner Tim Keyes and managing director John Nelms.After a miserable start to the campaign, the Americans’ dream of cementing their team as a force in the Premiership and, eventually, taking the club to a new stadium looked in danger of crumbling around them.Confirmation of just how dire the need for an emergency rebuild came in his first game in charge when the roof fell in during a - defeat at Livi. It showed how flimsy the foundations of the team were as they collapsed under the weight of the home team’s excellence at set-pieces.Almost exactly four months on and after that second visit to the Tony Macaroni Arena under the new boss, the structure looks much more sound.And it’s all thanks to the kind of speedy reconstruction he undertook at County and of which Knowles and his team would be proud. For the team that ran out against Livi at the weekend bore no resemblance to the one McIntyre had to work with when he first headed there.Not one of the players in the starting XI in October were on from the start this time and of the  who were involved on that first day,  have left the club.Only Kenny Miller, Cammy Kerr and Elliott Parish remain and, of those three, veteran Miller was the sole participant in the vital - victory.For McIntyre, to bring about almost a complete change in such a short space of time has been a gamble, one that will only be confirmed as paying offhis team are still in the Premiership come the end of the season.It’s one, though, that represents his best chance of success and it is very much a case of so far so good.While Dundee under him remain a work in progress, the signs of improvement have been there for all to see.Since the end of the winter break there have been two wins, two draws and just one defeat in five league outings.By some margin that’s been the best run of form in the top flight so far this term.If it continues there is every reason to believe that target of building a team good enough for this level by the end of the season will have been achieved.Andthat is the case, fans will be hoping given more time, the manager will be able to set about putting together something even more impressive for next season and beyond.

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: First phase of 32m refurbishment completed at Inverness school
story: THE first phase of a major refurbishment programme at an Inverness primary school has been completed.Two new classrooms have opened at Smithton Primary, much to the delight of principal teacher Lynne Macdonald who said the new facilities increased opportunities for its  children as well as staff.Pupils have also got a new a multiuse games area.ldquoItrsquos made a huge dference, she said.ldquoIt gives us a lot more space and just little things like having blackout blinds on sunny days and having all the children in seats at the same height really helps.The pound. million refurbishment project to address the schoolrsquos current and future capacity needs began last April.Once completed, it will see a total of five additional classrooms created along with two support needs rooms, a dedicated space for senior pupils and an extended gym hall.Local councillor Trish Robertson said it was excellent to see the project start to take shape.ldquoThe expansion was badly needed and having the extra space must be better for the children, she said. ldquoIrsquom really pleased itrsquos gone up so quickly.Iain MacDonald, special works manager for Morgan Sindall, which is carrying out the renovation work, said construction was currently on track for completion by September.ldquoThe most important thing for us has been not to interrupt the daily activity of the school, he said.ldquoBut another big thing is giving the kids a good experience of construction ndash therersquos a perception that construction is about the trades but therersquos so much more to get involved in.Miss Macdonald added: ldquoThe workers have been great. They always make sure they receive any deliveries before am which really helps and means the construction isnrsquot impacting the children. Thatrsquos the most important thing.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Funding blow to Highland food banks charity
story: North-based charity Blythswood Care has issued a public appeal for more donations after it lost an annual pound, recycling grant from Highland Council in the recent local authority budget.The charity which has one of the largest networks of food banks in the Highlands handles around  tonnes of clothing donations a year at its Evanton depot of which more than  per cent was reused or recycled.Previously the council financially supported the recycling work and some local authority properties already host textile banks for taking unwanted clothing deposits but this year withdrew support.The council had to plug an almost pound million financial hole in its budget amid shrinking government grants for core services, the moves was called a ldquobody blow by operations manager Ian Matheson who admitted the loss of the recycling grant is not a complete surprise.ldquoWe recognise that the Council has been faced with hard decisions. Wersquove enjoyed a mutually beneficial partnership with Highland Council for over  years and we really appreciate that, he said.ldquoTheir support has enabled us to develop our re-use and recycling activities, reducing waste, providing local employment and raising support for projects such as Blythswoodrsquos Highland Food Bank.ldquoDonations of clothing, bric-a-brac and quality furniture from the general public are going to be more important to us than ever as we aim to continue this aspect of our work despite the loss of this grant.The organisation processes more than , tonnes of donations a year at its Evanton depot, producing goods for its charity shops and selling on to processors in other parts of the country.Mr Matheson said ldquoWe have to constantly review all that we do and consider what efficiencies we can make. You can help us now by giving our shops your custom and donations.ldquoAll donations will be gratefully received so we can have continuity of employment ndash because this is about jobs too ndash as well as maintain service provision.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have had very positive discussions with Blythswood and these are ongoing about how we can possibly work together in the future.Blythswood welcomes donations of textiles, footwear, bric-a-brac, small electrical goods, books and good quality furniture.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious
story: UNCERTAINTY over the UKrsquos withdrawal from the European Union is causing people to delay home improvements according to an Inverness company.Cairngorm Windows has enjoyed its best start to a year in  years but managing director David Dowling says domestic customers are holding off finalising orders.ldquoPeople carrying out house improvements are approaching us but Brexit is delaying them from pressing the button he said.ldquoIn addition, our German fitted kitchen supplier have notied us of a . per cent import duty tax on all deliveries after March  in the absence of a deal going through.ldquoHowever, wersquove a record-breaking forward workbook thanks to the strong volume of orders from housebuilders while council contracts are at their highest level in  years.A pound, new computer operated cutting machine was fitted in January to drive forward Cairngormrsquos high-tech production process which saw a record , windows manufactured last year.The company aims to produce , windows this year and break the , barrier next year.Mr Dowling said housebuilders like Tulloch Homes, Springfield Homes, Compass and Scotframe had signicantly stepped up their forward orders while windows were being sold as far away as Swindon.Wersquove a strong domestic business where we supply and fit from fitted windows to fitted kitchens, he said.ldquoBut customers are currently telling us theyrsquore holding off the spend because of Brexit causing uncertainty to household budgets.ldquoWe hope that situation clears before too long.The company, which employs  people, installed a pound, automatic welder and corner cutter last year.It has been in business for  years.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Sugars night set to be sweet for Highland Hospice
story: AN evening of fun, quality entertainment and good food has been promised by an Inverness man who is raising money for the Highland Hospice.Alastair Kennedy, communications director at Global Energy Group and chairman of Nigg Skills Academy, is calling on local businesses to try and help with his fundraising for this yearrsquos Strictly Inverness dancing competition.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom hoping that the business community will support this amazing cause as they have done in the past.Known to his friends as Sugar, Mr Kennedy will be hosting a dinner called Sugarrsquos Strictly Big Night at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on April .The black tie tartan event will consist of live music from local band Torridon as well as an auction, quiz and a raffle, with all proceeds going to the hospice.Mr Kennedy is reaching out to the local business community to come along and support the event so he can raise as much money as possible.The director of Ross County Football Club is well known for his enjoyable hosting of hospitality at their home matches over the past  years, and thinks he has the the expertise and dry sense of humour to host another entertaining and enjoyable evening for all.As the oldest ever competitor in Strictly Inverness, Mr Kennedy was inspired to get involved in this yearrsquos event after sadly losing his mother to cancer in . She spent her final days in the hospice.ldquoTheir facilities and the care they provided for my mum was just so wonderful and considerate, he said.ldquoThey looked after her so well in her last days with us. I said at the time that I must, at some point in the future, do something to raise much-needed funds for the hospice, and with it being their th Strictly anniversary year, I just thought maybe now is the time.ldquoThere are lots of couples competing for the Strictly Inverness title and there is already great camaraderie being built up between us all.ldquoThis is not so much about winning, itrsquos more about raising money for this most worthy cause and everyone is working so hard not just in dance training, but in raising money by whatever means. I am hoping my business connections will assist me in being able to create a great night, but also raise as much money as possible for the hospice.Tables cost pound for  people and anyone interested should contact Mr Kennedy via Global Energy Group.Strictly Inverness also raises money for Inverness Ice Centre, which hosts the showdown from May .Monday  Feb  : AM

title: shinnie double secures seventh straight away win for aberdeen
story: ABERDEEN secured a seventh straight away victory as skipper Graeme Shinnie fired a devastating double to dump St Johnstone - in Perth.Club captain Shinnie netted superb goals either side of the break to move the Dons to within two points of second placed Rangers who are in action tomorrow.Aberdeen made two changes to the side held - at home to Premiership bottom club St Mirren.last weekend.Dom Ball came in for Tommie Hoban who suffered a season ending cruciate ligament injury against the Buddies at the weekend.Hoban, who was on loan from Premier League Watford, will undergo surgery.Also coming into the starting line-up was Connor McLennan with Niall McGinn dropping to the bench.Ball went into the right back position normally occupied by Shaleum Logan who it has been confirmed will undergo surgery on an ankle injury and could be ruled out for the season.On loan Rotherham defender Ball impressed in the right-back role.Aberdeen grabbed the lead in the th minute when Ball stole the ball off Kennedy before sliding a pass to Graeme SHINNIE.Scotland international Shinnie cut past Sean Goss before unleashing a precision right footed shot past Cammy Bell from the edge of the penalty area.It was a quality finish from Shinnie, who is out of contract at the end of the season and has yet to make a decision on his future.Aberdeen have offered Shinnie a lucrative new contract but the Pittodrie club remain in limbo..Shinnie was again at the heart of the action in the st minute to recover a precarious situation for Aberdeen as on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe lost possession in the St Johnstone half when pushing forward.It created a hole at the back that Goss exploited with a superb cross field ball flighted in behind the fractured rear-guard to release Chris Kane in on goal.Just as he was about to shoot from  yards out Shinnie made up vital ground before pitching in with a tackle to dispossess him.In the th minute Aberdeen were denied when Gary Mackay-Steven met a McLennan cross to unleash a  footed right footed volley that keeper Bell blocked.Moments later Dons keeper Joe Lewis was called into action as he tipped a  yard header from Murray Davidson over the bar.In the th minute teenager Lewis Ferguson, who this week signed a two year contract extension until , fired a powerful  yard drive across the face of goal and just wide.Aberdeen should have increased their advantage in the th minute when Shinnie burst into the box to collect a pass from Stewart before crossing low to find McLennan in space.However the winger, back into the starting line up, blasted over from  yards.The woodwork denied Saints in the th minute when a drilled cross from Kennedy came off the outstretched boot of Mikey Devlin and cracked off the post.Captain SHINNIE netted his second goal to make the three points safe when he won the ball on the half-way line before powering up-field.Shinnie then unleashed a superb left footed  yard drive beyond keeper Bell.ABERDEEN: Lewis, Ball, Devlin, Considine, Lowe, Ferguson, Shinnie, Stewart, Mackay-Steven, McLennan, Cosgrove.Subs: McGinn , May , Gleeson .Subs not used: Cerny, Virtanen, Campbell, WilsonST JOHNSTONE: Bell, Tanser, Shaughnessy, Davidson, Kane, Wotherspoon, Kerr, Foster, Craig, Goss, Kennedy.Subs: Watt , Swanson , Hendry .Subs not used: Hurst, Alston,  Callachan, Keown.Referee: Euan Anderson

title: aberdeen butcher installs second defib following community support
story: An Aberdeen butcher is to install a second defibrillator near his shop after receiving overwhelming support from the community.HS Milne and Sons in Bucksburn already has the vital le-saving piece of equipment set up outside its Inverurie Road branch but now, thanks to generous customers, provision will double in the area.The new defibrillator will be placed at Davy’s Fish Bar on Sclattie Park and has been bought thanks to the Butchers at the Heart of the Community initiative.The scheme, which is Scotland-wide, was set up by Hunters of Kinross and is supported by Scottish Craft Butchers, the Scotch Butchers Club and Save a Le Scotland.Its main aim is to help and encourage people to be ready and confident to use CPR equipment in the event of somebody suffering a cardiac arrest.Kenny Milne, owner of HS Milne and Sons, became involved with the scheme last summer.He said: “The community helped us raise money for the defibrillator which is outside the store.“It was installed in November. We originally only planned to install one but the money kept coming in and we had enough for another one so we spoke to Davy’s Fish Bar and they said they would back it.”The defibrillators can be purchased for around £, – a reduced price because they were bought in bulk through the Butchers at the Heart of the Community scheme.Both defibrillators will be accessibly to the public when needed.If an emergency  call is made and the defibrillator is registered with the Scottish Ambulance Service, the nearest device can be located and a code given to the caller to unlock it.Once opened, instructions are provided.For heart-attack victims, the community defibrillators could prolong their lives by vital minutes, because the more time that passes during a cardiac arrest without assistance, the less chance there is of survival.Mr Milne said he was overwhelmed by the community’s generosity.He said: “Most of it was raised in the shop. We also raised about £ through a Just Giving page.“Local musicians put together a concert at Newhills Church, and a second one at Bucksburn Church which raised quite a bit of money. It was all raised by the community.”The equipment is expected to be installed shortly.Douglas Scott, chief executive of Scottish Craft Butchers, said: “This project is all about enabling butchers to save the lives of people in their community, raising money to provide defibrillators and training staff on how to do CPR.”

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: districts week 08
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsA poem a dayDo you like poetry  Or would you like to spend a little time listening to your own heart  Spring-time is marked out for reflection, new growth and the warmth of generosity in the Christian tradition. It is the time of Lent: the old Germanic word for spring-time. Our hearts are bidden to imitate the snow-drops: to come up from the darkness, raise themselves into the sunlight, and then fill the world with gladness.Parishioners from Ardrishaig, Christ Church, Lochgilphead and Glassary are joining together this Lent to read a poem a day through the  days of Lent and then Easter week. The poems have been chosen are in a beautul book, entitled The Heart’s Time, by Janet Morley. The poems come from across the English-speaking world, over the last four centuries. One poem is set for each day, accompanied by a short explanation, a reflection, and a brief suggestion for our own thinking.Parishoners will be reading the poems at home for those who wish it there will be meetings to share thoughts and inspiration at Ardrishaig Church during the weeks of Lent and at Christ Church on Sundays. Other meetings could be arranged, formally or informally.You can order the book from Fr Simon Mackenzie by emailing dr.lachlan@zen or calling  , or directly from Argyll Book Centre. Lent begins this year on Ash Wednesday March .Lynx reintroduced to Argyll and ButeFollowing on from an announcement that they were surveying Scotland in late , the Lynx UK Trust have identied three locations which could act as release sites for the medium-sized cats, including the Kintyre peninsula.Independent scientic research has shown that Scotland#s forest could sustain around  of the cats, which ecologists believe could help control the UK#s over-populated deer herds, leading to a regeneration of forest ecosystems that would benefit all of the UK#s native wildle.No lynx attack on a human has ever been recorded anywhere, though lynx reintroduction is a controversial issue with sheep farming unions concerned that the cats would decimate herds, though numerous independent studies make clear that sheep are an exceptionally rare target for lynx, even when the two live side by side.A public drop in consultation is scheduled for Tuesday March  from pm to pm in Tarbert village hall.E.ON donated to Arrochar roof insulationVehicles used by the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team will benefit from being garaged at a more constant temperature this winter after the E.ON Energising Communities Fund paid for £, worth of insulation to be fitted at the rescue post.The volunteers making up the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team provide search and rescue assistance throughout Strathclyde when requested by Police Scotland and can be called upon  hours a day,  days a year.  Working across all mountainous terrain and in any weather condition, they use three vehicles which are kept in the garage attached to the mountain rescue post in Arrochar which was built in .After mechanics identied condensation and corrosion as the cause of the vehicles’ increasingly frequent and expensive mechanical and electrical problems, heating was installed at the garage last year to reduce their maintenance costs and improve their reliability. It was then realised that roof insulation was necessary to lower the cost of the heating.Douglas Philp, team secretary for Arrochar Mountain Rescue, said: #As a charity, we’re totally dependent on donations, grants and volunteers. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayrshire hospice marks 30th birthday
story: NewsAyrshire Hospice marks th birthday as staff and volunteers reflect on three decades of serviceThe milestone birthday has been marked with a series of events and celebrations.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor  years it has touched the lives of thousands in Ayrshire and far beyond. Its mission  To enrich the remaining days of those facing le-limiting illness. The work of the Ayrshire Hospice, irreplaceable since February , has formed part of the region’s fabric over three decades. But at pound, per day to fund bosses admit they owe their biggest debt to the public. Reflecting on the landmark birthday, chief executive Mandy Yule said: “Our message to the wonderful people of Ayrshire is ‘thank you’. “We wouldn’t be able to deliver the level of care we doit wasn’t for their support. “We have an incredible group of volunteers and fundraisers across Ayrshire, some of whom have given their time for over  years, and without the fundraising efforts the hospice wouldn’t be here.” Since opening its doors on Racecourse Road the base has become a centre of care, comfort, compassion and dignity to more than , patients.  But its true origins go back even further to a group of hard-working volunteers who set up their own trust in . Their goal was to raise the necessary funds to open a hospice in Ayrshire. After as initial target of pound, was met within  months the next task of finding a suitable location threw up Racecourse Road. Building work began in  and, with it, the hospice service was launched with the appointment of two home care nurses. From its earliest days fundraising has served the heart of the hospice. And it is that invaluable support that the hospice – which has almost  staff and volunteers – is recognising during its th year.   Mandy said: “Because of their efforts we have access to some of the best palliative care treatments available, allowing us to give our patients comfort and quality of le. “We have been privileged to give thousands of patients and their families the care and support they need, both at the hospice itself or wherever they have lived in Ayrshire, over the last  years and we take great pride in that”. To help mark the anniversary a special memory tree has been created giving the opportunity to leave reflections and memories of the hospice. Mandy said: “We never take the compassionate and continued support of the hospice by the people of Ayrshire for granted. “The memory tree gives people the chance to leave their own memories or thoughts about the hospice and be part of our celebration.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: blooming marvellous ayr flower show
story: NewsBlooming marvellous as Ayr flower show sIt promises to be the biggest yet, with more classes and more entertainment.ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsTop team Chairman Tom Brown and Secretary Irene Yuill "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe third Ayr and District Flower Show will be back at Ayr Racecourse in August. It promises to be the biggest yet, with more classes and more entertainment. It is being switched this year to a Friday and Saturday to avoid a clash with the Sunday market. Ticket prices will remain the same at just pound and under-s free, new secretary Irene Yuill revealed. The experienced administrator, now retired from Auchincruive College, has been drafted in to assist chairman Tom Brown and the committee of volunteers. The show will be staged on August  and . Secretary Irene revealed winners will not get a prize money cannot buy and added: “Adults will no longer get money for winning classes. Instead they will get a fine crystal keepsake. This will be engraved and presented for the best exhibit in each section.” New classes will be introduced for the first time this year including Handicrafts, Baking, Preserves and Walking Sticks. Lego Models and a Miniature Garden in a seed tray will be added to the junior section. All classes will be FREE to enter.   There will be a wide range of trade stands including some craft stalls. Ayr Racecourse will again run a Food Market in the Princess Suite. There will be Cookery and Floral Demonstrations. Irene added: “For the first time this year we will be joined by the Model Railway Club who will set up a display and musical entertainment will be on offer.” The organisers are looking for as many volunteers to help, including stewarding and unseen work in the background such as stage building and dismantling. Chairman Tom Brown said: “To run the show we rely on the good will of the many volunteers who give up their time. We must thank everyone who has helped make Ayr  District Flower Show the success it has been over the last two years and hope we can count on their support again this year. “It is a great family day out with something for everyone to enjoy.” *Enlist your help by mailing ayranddistrictflowershow@gmail or  .

title: malawi partners set top tour
story: NewsMalawi partners get set for top tour of AyrshireErnest Chirwa and Francis Juma from Bandawe All Girls Secondary School and Bandawe Primary School will embark on a tour of Ayrshire from March  - .ShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB NewsFrancis Juma with Bill Duncan, Elder from Alloway Parish Church "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAlloway Parish Church are gearing up to welcome partnering head teachers from across the globe next month. Following the success of the Alloway Malawi Mission , the church, in partnership with Alloway and Doonfoot Primary Schools have invited two head teachers from their partner schools in northern Malawi to visit Ayrshire in March. Ernest Chirwa and Francis Juma from Bandawe All Girls Secondary School and Bandawe Primary School will embark on a tour of Ayrshire from March  - . A full itinerary has been organised including working with and observing the teachers and head teachers across local schools including Belmont Academy and Wellington School. Ernest Chirwa and Francis Juma will attend worship at Alloway Parish Church on both Sundays, and will join families at Messy Church on March . And a fun-filled community “Scottish Night” with ceilidh dancing, entertainment and a quiz will be held in the church halls on Saturday, March  from . – pm, to really make the visitors welcome. Alloway and Doonfoot pupils are very excited to meet the head teachers and to learn more about their friends from Malawi. Mr Juma and Mr Chirwa will also be able to attend the wonderful Pop UK recording, with concerts set to be held in the church on March . story: NewsScots skating star set to follow Dancing on Ice heroes Torvill and DeanPrestwick lad Lewis Gibson is being touted as the next big thing in British ice dance and has his sights set on the next Winter Olympics in Beijing.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA skating star who caught the ice bug while watching telly is being primed for a shot at the Olympics.
