I knew roughly where to look but purposefully hadnrsquot brought the map so that we had a challenge to find the lsquochairrsquo. We knew what it looked like and that we needed to walk along the upper path, not the one that heads for the beach.We went the wrong way at first and got stuck in a mass of sea buckthorn, but on reflection that just added to the sense of adventure and achievement. We soon found our way and then suddenly there it was, up on Gullane Hill. The kids ran excitedly towards the stones, shouting: ldquoFound it, found it.I felt quite exhilarated at the discovery, and to be honest impressed by the sight of the Kingrsquos Chair. I can see how it got its name, as it looks something like a majestic reclining armchair. The two boulders on either side of it look like sentries keeping watch.The kids sat on it, of course, and I had to wait my turn after my we, who reckoned it could just as easily be a lsquoQueenrsquos Chairrsquo.When I finally got a chance to seat my majestic posterior on the chair, I realised the view was majestic as well, with Gullane Beach very visible in the near distance.I reflected on the fact we had recently visited Edinburgh Castle and seen the Stone of Destiny or Stone of Scone, along with the crown jewels. This rather uninspiring stone in Edinburgh Castle may be the coronation stone used for  years in England, but it is not, I am sure, the coronation stone used by ancient kings of Scotland, despite official claims that it is.I think itrsquos pretty clear that Edward I never got his hands on the real Stone of Destiny and I am convinced it has remained in Scotland, hidden somewhere, ever since. It occurred to me that this stone actually better fitted the early description of the original coronation stone at Scone than the one in Edinburgh Castle.ldquoImaginethis is the real Stone of Destiny and has been here all the time, I said fancully out loud. I know it isnrsquot, of course, but I have to saythis Kingrsquos Chair was on display at Edinburgh Castle it would certainly look more authentic.But sadly there seems to be no recorded tradition connected to this Kingrsquos Chair. I could find no story, or reference to the origin of its name. Perhaps some local people have some information on this There is an entry from the s that records the name, citing locals as the source, so there is some historic veracity in its title. But no suggestion is offered for the origin of the name, or any tradition associated with the stone. Its geology I could not say but it doesnrsquot seem to be a glacial erratic.And so we are left to wonder. We discussed how the stone got here and how it got its name. Maybe some children played here many generations ago and gave the boulder its title. Perhaps a Viking king who landed on Gullane Beach sat himself down on this natural throne to survey his warriors at their bloody work.Whatever the origin, the name, the location and the nature of the stone make this a worthwhile and fun discovery, even without a firm legend attached to it.And as I sat on the chair I watched smoke billowing from the coastline a little further to the west, close to the edge of Aberlady nature reserve. What caused the fire I didnrsquot know, but even from a distance it seemed destructive.It was a prophetic sight to witness from the Kingrsquos Chair. It looked like a burning coastline from a Viking raid. Thankfully the distant screech of fire engines told us help was on the way. The children wanted to go see the fire, but we kept our distance from the flames and let the firefighters do their job.So the trip to the Kingrsquos Chair had been an adventure in more ways than one. On our way back, the children advanced dferent theories about the origin of the name. It was universally agreed that a story must be made, but no agreement on the actual tale.ldquoPerhaps, I said, ldquowe should leave it to the imagination of those who search for and discover it, so they can sit and feel the power of the place and get ideas.My imagination was certainly ablaze. I saw the leader of the ancient Gododdin tribe, King Loth, sitting on the stone, looking out to the Firth as he watched his terried daughter in a small coracle being taken out to the open sea, his brutal punishment for her defiance of his authority.The story would fit as her journey began at Aberlady Bay, and so her small craft would have been seen from the Kingrsquos Chair as it passed by, being pulled out to sea by one of the kingrsquos boats.Itrsquos all a fancy of my imagination, of course, but thatrsquos my story. Go find the Kingrsquos Chair for yourself and see what your imagination comes up with!

title: double-cash-boost-for-our-community-kitchen-project-in-haddington
story: Our Community Kitchen has been awarded more than pound,, which it will use over the next year.The bulk of the money has come from Big Lottery Scotland, with pound, awarded to see the group expand to three days a week from next month.Already, the project meets on a Tuesday at Haddington Bowling Club.In the coming weeks, it will also meet on a Wednesday and Thursday, hosting dozens of people at each session and serving a hearty three-course meal for a donation of pound.Elaine Gale, spokeswoman for the project, felt Our Community Kitchen was well on the road to being a success.She said: ldquoIt is so exciting for the area and just to see where we go next. There is hard work in the next six months as we build these two new days up.ldquoWhat I really love, what comes across very clear to everybody, is that there are no barriers at all.ldquoIt is people coming together, having something to eat, and natural things happen when people come together to eat. That, for me, is really special.ldquoThere is nobody specic invited ndash no age limits or ability ndash it is just people.ldquoIt is amazing people coming together, having some food and everybody is laughing their head off and having a blast.A further pound, was awarded by the Walk With Scott Foundation.Scott Glynn, who founded the charity, visited Our Community Kitchen last month and was impressed with what was on offer.A post on their social media said: ldquoIt was such a joy to see a project in action, people from all walks of le getting together to have lunch and a blether.ldquoThe smiles as they walked in and the contentment of a full belly after they had been served by wonderful volunteers was a joy to see.ldquoNothing was a trouble, and everything was done with a smile and a kind word.ldquoIt was decided to help this project with funding and we are proud to have offered them pound,, with the provision of having a couple of themed days: a Burns lunch, a Wimbledon day, a bowling day and, of course, their Christmas dinner ideas were suggested.For more information on the group, which meets at .pm at the bowling club on Wemyss Place, email elainegale@gmail

title: east-lothian-the-backdrop-for-budding-directors-movie-at-glasgow-film-festival
story: Connect was written and directed by Marilyn Edmond and premiered at the Glasgow Film Festival on Saturday.The film, which stars Kevin Guthrie, of Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them and Dunkirk, also features a number of East Lothian residents.Marilyn, who is originally from Prestonpans, was looking forward to the moviersquos first screening.She said: ldquoIt is really cool, amazing actually.ldquoIrsquom really excited about it and really happy the world premiere is in Scotland.Marilyn, who now lives in Glasgow, has been involved in film and television for nearly  years.She has worked as an assistant director on programmes ranging from Waterloo Road and Lovesick to Sunshine on Leith.However, Connect is her first time as writer and director, with the film also getting a second showingduring the -day festival. Both screenings are sold out.Marilyn revealed it was a tragedy that had moved her to create her first feature- film.She said: ldquoWhen I was working on one of the previous jobs, there was a guy that was an extra and he ended up committing suicide.ldquoIt just totally threw me.ldquoHe had posted on Facebook about how his le was brilliant and he was so happy and four months later he committed suicide.ldquoI was just gobsmacked with it.ldquoHe was only  and that really sticks with me.ldquoI feel his le had only just really started and I was really saddened by the news.ldquoAccompanied by all the stories in the media, it is quite a big subject.Writing on Connect began in November , with filming getting under way in May last year.That was wrapped up by November, with the film now finished and ready to be seen by the public.Thirty-seven-year-old Marilyn, who lived in North Berwick at the time of the filming, said: ldquoConnect is about a young man who is struggling and he is feeling suicidal.ldquoHe gets saved by a stranger and then is encouraged to live his le and reconnect with his family and friends ndash all the while he is battling his dark secret.Steampunk Coffee and Turnbullrsquos Home Hardware, both North Berwick, are among county locations used in the film, with Gullane Day Centre and Dunbar also featuring.There are also a handful of familiar faces as well, with Lynne Turnbull and Kenny Ainslie, who has carried boxer Josh Taylorrsquos Commonwealth super lightweight title to the ring, among those starring in the film.

title: theresa-may-takes-cue-from-italian-counterpart-around-pool-table

title: new-independent-group-of-mps-to-meet-for-first-time
story: Eight Labour MPs were followed by three Tories in quitting their parties to form a new centrist grouping in potentially the most signicant realignment in British politics in a generation.After the fanfare and press conferences of last week, they will meet formally for the first time as a group on Monday behind closed doors at Westminster.Ex-Labour member Chuka Umunna insisted at the weekend that they were not yet a party or a movement, with a fully worked out programme for government, but simply a group of independent MPs.Members have said they are united by a shared ldquonon-tribal belief in ldquoprogressive values combined with deep unhappiness at the directions their former parties had taken, particularly on Brexit.Among the ex-Labour MPs there was also anger at what they said was the failure of the party leadership to deal with the spread of anti-Semitism in the party.However they are likely to face pressure to move quickly to formally establish themselves as a party ndash with reports that some former Labour backers are ready to help bankroll them.Mr Umunna, a former shadow minister, played down reports that he was favourite to be the first leader, although he acknowledged that he wanted to play the ldquobiggest role in the group.However former Tory Sarah Wollaston told BBC Radio rsquos The Westminster Hour: ldquoI think we would all be very happy to see Chuka in that role, but we donrsquot know over the coming days and weeks whether others will join us and somebody  may emerge.ldquoBut therersquos clearly an appetite from the public to know whorsquos going to be our spokesperson and I think thatrsquos reasonable.She predicted that more Tories would quit to join them following Mrs Mayrsquos announcement that she was delaying the ldquomeaningful vote on her Brexit deal to March  ndash just  days before Britain is due to leave.ldquoI think there are very many MPs who are interested in joining us, she said.ldquoI think a lot of people are watching to see what happens this week. So I think some of my colleagues will also be considering their positions following that announcement.Meanwhile Labour has declined to comment on reports that Jeremy Corbyn is to meet with former justice secretary Lord Falconer of Thoroton to discuss how the party can tackle the issue of anti-Semitism.Mr Corbyn was said to be considering asking the peer, a former flatmate of Tony Blair, to be the partyrsquos anti-Semitism surveillance commissioner, with full oversight of how it handles complaints and decision-making processes.Over the weekend deputy leader Tom Watson warned Mr Corbyn that he needed to ldquoeradicate anti-Semitism in the partyhe hoped ever to become prime minister.After the Jewish MP Luciana Berger was driven out by ldquoracist bullies, Mr Watson said it was clear that reforms introduced by general secretary Jennie Formby to deal with the issue had failed.

title: regina-king-named-best-supporting-actress-at-the-oscars
story: The If Beale Street Could Talk star fended off competition from The Favouritersquos Emma Stone and Rachel Weisz, as well as Marina de Tavira for Roma and Amy Adams for Vice.Collecting her gong for her role in the adaptation of the novel by James Baldwin, adapted and directed by Barry Jenkins, King said: ldquoTo be standing here representing one of the great artists of our time ndash James Baldwin ndash itrsquos a little surreal.ldquoJames Baldwin birthed this baby and Barryyou nurtured her, you surrounded her with so much love and support, so itrsquos appropriate for me to be standing here because Irsquom an example of what it looks like when support and love is poured into someone.Speaking to her mother who had accompanied her to the ceremony, King said: ldquoMom, I love you so much. Thank you for teaching me that God is always, always has been leaning in my directionhellip God is good all the time.Well said, @ReginaKing pic GuEoNrLgmdash The AcademyFebruary , The ceremony, which does not have a host this year after the Academyrsquos pick Kevin Hart stepped down following a row over historic homophobic tweets, opened with a performance by Queen and Adam Lambert.The band, who are the subject of the Freddie Mercury biopic Bohemian Rhapsody, performed a medley ofWe Will Rock You and We Are The Champions.They were followed by Tina Fey, Maya Rudolph and Amy Poehler, who took to the stage to poke fun at the drama that has surrounded the ceremony this year.Fey welcomed viewers to the ldquoone millionth Academy Awards, adding: ldquoWe are not your hosts but we are going to stand here a little too long so the people who get USA Today tomorrow will think we are.Rudolph added: ldquoSo just to update you, there is no host tonight, there wonrsquot be a popular movie category and Mexico is not paying for the wall.Poehler continued: ldquoWe wont be presenting awards during the commercials, but we will be doing commercials during the awards.The second prize of the night was handed to Free Solo, which was named best documentary feature.Roma and The Favourite went into the ceremony with the most nominations, with  apiece.

title: two-day-street-rave-taking-place-under-glasgow-motorway-this-summer
story: Platform  willto the city again for the two-day party under the bridge of West Street.After the success of last year, Platform  organisers have launched a second date, transforming into the cityrsquos only open-air techno street festival.Those behind the event will be confirming the full day-by-day lineup on Thursday, February . Tickets will go on sale the same day at am.:-hour car park rave under Glasgow rail bridges given go-aheadThe rave will happen on August  and .We reported back in June how the car park rave had been given the go-ahead to take place last summer by the council as organisers aimed to make it ldquoone of the best open-air street raves in Europe.The council heard at the time that the event was a positive way to bring young people in touch with mental health issues and that it had raised thousands for charity SAMH.Read more of todays top Glasgow stories

title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: Glasgow  Gateway to Scotland  The best Charles Rennie Mackintosh within 90 minutes
story: The striking beauty and modernity of the work was not fully appreciated in his letime, though the vision of its ambitious creator is now recognised and celebrated around the world. Brad Pitt, Barbra Streisand and Madonna are among Mackintoshrsquos fans, and his pioneering designs continue to influence popular culture, not least in film and television, where sci-fi classics such as Bladerunner, Inception, Doctor Who and Star Wars ndash Darth Vader sits on a Mackintosh-inspired chair in the Empire Strikes Back ndash paid tribute to his geometric style.Nothing, however, compares to seeing and experiencing Mackintoshs work in person, and Glasgow is the best place in world to do so. Sadly, his masterpiece, Glasgow School of Art, was devastated in a second fire last year, with the schoolrsquos management pledging to rebuild, though this will clearly take many years.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best film locationsThere have been more positive developments where, of course, not least the opening of Mackintosh at The Willow, the stunning restoration of the original Willow Tearooms building on Sauchiehall Street. In Dundee, meanwhile, the new VA Museum ndash a world-class celebration of Scottish and international design - has Mackintosh at its beating heart.ldquoToshie as he was known to his friends, remains an indelible presence in the west of Scotland, though sometimes even Glaswegians become complacent about their cityrsquos most creative son. But thanks to Mackintoshs extraordinary creativity across the mediums therersquos always something new and interesting to see, whether yoursquore being introduced to the work for the first time or are a lelong admirer. With this in mind, wersquove put together a list of the best places to experience Mackintosh this year, all within  minutes of Glasgow.Queens Cross ChurchStill something of an under-appreciated gem, the only church designed by Mackintosh showcases his early promise. The unfussy, gothic-inspired building sits inconspicuously at a busy urban intersection on the edge of Maryhill, between the city centre and Glasgowrsquos west end, and you might easily walk past. Those who go inside are in for a treat, however, as the fully-restored interior highlights not only Mackintoshs love for nature but his appreciation of all things Japanese - not to mention is sense of humour.A favourite place of the late Princess Margaret, the church is now the home of the Charles Rennie Mackintosh Society, and offers year-round workshops, seminars, exhibitions, walks and talks. Itrsquos also one of Glasgowrsquos most beautul, intimate and under-rated music venues and hosts a wide array of concerts and events throughout the year. Garscube Road, Glasgow. Entry: pound. Children free. MackintoshchurchScotland Street SchoolOne of the biggest and best-loved of all Mackintoshrsquos buildings, the school ndash designed between  and  ndash provides a double whammy in terms of visitor experience. As well as exploring the amazing architecture, you get the chance to explroe the history of Scottish education in the fantastic hands-on displays, exhibitions and live performances that are dotted around this eminently family-friendly museum. Scotland Street, Glasgow. Free entry. Glasgowle.org museumsGlasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best whisky and BurnsKelvingrove Museum and Art GalleryArgyle Street, Glasgow. Glasgowle.org museumsHouse for an Art LoverDesigned as an entry to a prestigious German architecture competition, House for an Art Lover was conceived by Mackintosh in , but after being disqualied on a technicality, it was never built. Not in the architectrsquos letime, anyhow. The project was ambitiously resurrected in the s and the house finally opened in Glasgowrsquos south side,  years after its original conception, as country house, exhibition space, venue, cafeacute, restaurant and artistsrsquo studios, all set in beautul grounds. Dumbreck Road, Glasgow. Entry: pound pound.. Children under  go free. HouseforanartloverMackintosh at The WillowRe-opened last year in the citys Sauchiehall Street after an ambitious and meticulous poundm restoration, Mackintosh collaborator Kate Cranstonrsquos most iconic tea rooms provide a glorious insight into the pairrsquos creative partnership. Conceived as a complete work of art - a Gesamtkunstwerk - Mackintosh, alongside his we Margaret, designed every element of the building, inside and out, including furniture, wall decorations and accessories. But this is not a museum so much as a lively place to meet, eat, socialise and hold events. The afternoon tea is a delight.A new on-site visitor centre, staffed by volunteers, provides a wealth of information about the Mackintosh Cranston Macdonald legacy in Glasgow.- Sauchiehall Street. MackintoshatthewillowGlasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best film locationsThe LighthouseMackintoshrsquos first public commission was originally designed in  for The Herald, but since  it has housed event spaces, a cafe, Glasgowrsquos Centre for Architecture and Design, and a permanent exhibition and learning centre dedicated to its architect. The rooftop viewing area also provides some of the most spectacular views in the city.The Lighthouse, Mitchell Lane, Glasgow. Entry free.The Mackintosh HouseArguably nowhere better showcases Mackintoshrsquos genius as an interior designer than this wonderful recreation of the house he shared in the West End of the city, right next to the University of Glasgow, with Margaret.Featuring a meticulous reassembly of the principal apartments of their now demolished home in nearby Southpark Avenue, the apartments are filled with their original furniture and highlight the strikingly modern decorative vision shared by this remarkably modern couple.The Mackintosh House at the Hunterian, University of Glasgow. Entry: pound pound. Under s go free.VA DundeeBuilt on the banks of the Firth of Tay in Dundee, renowned Japanese architect Kengo Kuma ndash himself an acolyte of Mackintosh - has created a dramatic, beautul and entirely al base for Scotlandrsquos first dedicated design museum, with Mackintosh at the centre.Fully restored after half a century in storage, the magnicent Oak Room ndash the centrepiece of Miss Cranstonrsquos Ingram Street Tea Rooms in Glasgow ndash has been installed as the permanent centrepiece of the Scottish Design Gallery, on loan from Glasgow Museums.Riverside Esplanade, Dundee. Vam.ac.ukGlasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best whisky and BurnsHill House, HelensburghThis ldquohome for the future in Helensburgh, an hour north west of Glasgow, is a particular favourite with many Toshie fans. Built for publisher Walter Blackie in , it is his domestic masterpiece and features many of the most recognisable designs and schemes, including the rose mot stencils.Problems with the exterior harling have always plagued the building, leading to water damage, and owners the National Trust for Scotland are currently building a ldquobox" around the house to protect it until a long-term solution can be found.Hill House is closed while the box is constructed, but will re-open to visitors in late spring.Upper Colquhoun St, Helensburgh. Entry pound. pound.. nts.org.ukMackintosh Club, HelensburghAnother Helensburgh gem is the Mackintosh Club, designed in  and now a hub for art, architecture and music.Sinclair Street, Helensburgh, G SU. Entry: pound. Mackintosh.clubDaily Record BuildingDesigned in  and tucked away from the bustle in a city centre lane, Mackintoshrsquos commission for the Daily Record now houses hip bar, cafe and music venue Stereo, and is a must-see stop on any city centre walking tour. Look upwards and you will see the striking use of colour on the faccedilade, which skilfully combines sculpted sandstone and white glazed bricks to maximise light. Listen carefully and you can almost hear the clack of the typewriters.Renfield Lane, Glasgow.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland a partnership between People Make Glasgow and Glasgow Airport, in association with The Herald, aims to attract more US visitors and capitalise on a recent growth in overseas tourists by highlighting the cityrsquos position as both a must-see destination in itself, and the ideal base for accessing Scotlandrsquos landscapes, history and culture.Delta flies direct to Glasgow from JFK www.delta.United flies direct from Newark www.united.

title: Rosemary Goring  Now is the time for the Catholic Church   s own Reformation
story: For this book Martel has conducted more than , interviews in the Vatican City in Rome, and across the world. He has spoken to priests, cardinals, bishops, monsignors, papal ambassadors, seminarians and the Swiss Guard. His conclusion, which will shock some and come as no surprise to others, is that about  per cent of the clergy in the Vatican state are gay. In other words, the HQ of a church that will not bless same-sex relationships, and forbids its clergy to have sex lives, is riddled with hyprocisy at its very core.Of these  per cent, Martel writes, some are celibate or in denial, others are living with their partners, or resort to prostitutes. A rule of thumb is that the more vehemently a cleric condemns homosexuality, the more likely he is to be in the closet himself. Hence the behaviour of the Colombian cardinal, Alfonso Lopez Trujillo. He was in the vanguard of the churchrsquos mission to prevent gay marriage. As the dire consequences of the Aids epidemic became clear, contrary to commonsense and compassion, he refused to encourage the use of condoms. Here was someone eager to be seen to uphold traditional values. Yet Martel claims that Trujillo, who died in , used male prostitutes.There are examples closer to home, among them the late Cardinal Keith OrsquoBrien, who pursued a similarly denunciatory anti-gay agenda, despite his own homosexuality and predatory behaviour. In fact, it doesnrsquot matter where you look. Throughout the Catholic churchrsquos parishes, globally and locally, there has been the mother of all cover-ups, not just in the buttoned-up past, but right now, here, today.You could say the church has been built on lies: countless men forced to hide who they really are, or to seek refuge in an all-male environment where they could find illicit love behind closed doors. Those clergy who were straight must have found themselves in a bewildering labyrinth of duplicity. That such depths of deceit have been allowed to thrive says all you need to know about the controlling power of those at the heart of the church.Martel believes that Pope Francis has earned enemies by adopting a very untypical approach. ldquoWho am I to judge  he replied, when askedhe condemned homosexuals, thereby loosening the ground beneath the feet of those in the Holy See who donrsquot want their secrets aired, or their way of le altered.The revelation of such widespread double standards is an echo of the medieval churchrsquos calamitous abuse of power and wealth. Out of it has sprung a culture where bullying, intimidation and blackmail have flourished. Andthat has been going on in this sphere, you can be sure it will have spilled over into every other part of the churchrsquos affairs.In the wake of the revelation of child abuse on a grand scale in the church, you begin to see why hiding the truth was the default position. This is not to make a link between homosexuality and child abuse but to see why the ecclesiastical authorities were so quick, and adept, at making the problem disappear. In avoiding scandal, they were intent on protecting their own rather than those who had been so grievously harmed.With evidence of institutionalised deception of the extent Martel claims, the church brings shame on itself: not for the numbers of priests who are gay, but for the willingness to lie about it, and to break vows, and the spirit of vocation, to an extent that will appall devout parishioners.Now is the time for the Catholic Churchrsquos own Reformation. No-one can any longer doubt that the le expected of a Catholic priest is unhealthy. And since there is no biblical injunction on him to be celibate, why can this not be changed  Already the church is embracing married Anglican vicars in flight from the ordination of women. Why not allow Catholic clergy the same right to open relationships, whether they be gay or straight Until the double-speak on which the modern church stands is addressed, there is no hope of winning back the faithful who have lost all trust and respect in this once revered institution. Obliging men to profess one thing while being another, is psychological torment. The denial of clergyrsquos humanity and self-expression is as cruel as anything the Inquisition devised. If the Vatican could bring itself to accept homosexuality, and gay marriage, and a non-celibate priesthood, it would be a truly Christian act.Read more: Cardinal Keith OBrien asked for forgiveness

title: joanna-blythman-reviews-locarno-in-glasgow
story: WErsquoVE decided to have one farinaceous main course at Locarno to keep down the total cost because the other mains are so expensive: pound. to pound.. I instantly exclude the ldquorissottoat pound. and pound.. Experience tells me that bad spelling often augurs bad cooking.With just a hint of a shoulder-shrugging ldquowhat do you expect me to do about it  attitude, our waiter breaks the news that all four, yes four, ravioli dishes listed on the menu are not available.So we alight on cacio e pepe, Romersquos favourite pasta, where the art is to leave just enough cooking water for the pasta to form a sauce when fresh Pecorino and ground black pepper is added.Therersquos confusion. Our waiter mishears: he thinks we want the catch of the day , so maybe the chef was flustered.Even so, Locarnorsquos clueless attempt at this classic would surely be greeted with derision in its home city: over-boiled spaghetti, so dry that it forms a mat, further clumped together by the plasticity of its cheese veneer, and not a speck of black pepper in sight.Seriously, I could use this sticky mass, Marx Brothers fashion, as a projectile. And pound for something parents might complain aboutserved as a school meal  What planet are they on here Irsquod say Locarno trades on its atmosphere, sort of swanky, clubby, with a bit of a Jazz Age vibe, white linen, classy chandeliers, black and white photos.The menu, like the pricing, is all over the place, a wacky compilation of everything from creamed Jalapentildeo chive soup and steak tartare to mince and tatties and controversial foie gras. Itrsquos an unhappy hybrid of Italian, French, and s Taste of Tartan.My first and only satisfactory dish here is caponata. It judges the tricky sweet-sour balance well the onions, celery and aubergines melt.Cock-a-leekieis disastrous, a murky broth with no chicken taste, mushy leeks cooked to khaki, vapid potatoes, dry chicken breast.Our waitress takes it away less than half-eaten without askingeverything is all right. Thatrsquos telling. Maybe she knows better than to ask for fear of a negative response.Irsquom one of relatively few people who actually enjoys calfrsquos liver, providing itrsquos properly cooked, but Irsquom looking at a plateful that even fills me with dread.The liver is deadly plain, without the crustiness Irsquod expect from the promised pan-frying in butter. Its sauce, said to be raspberry vinegar and caramelised onions, tastes to me like the smell my oven makes when it needs a good clean.Mashed potatoes have nothing going for them ndash too dry, lumpy, no perceptible butteriness, and it would appear that the kitchenrsquos savoir-faire with kaleonly extends to boiling it.This is another dish with that somethingrsquos-got-burnt-on-to-the-oven- floor whf. Itrsquos cleared away, largely uneaten. Again, no one seems to want to knowwhy.I canrsquot wait to escape home nowbut a table of  ndash all men, business account, naturally ndash is slowing down the already struggling front of house thatrsquos trying to serve customers and set new tables.Irsquom amazed to see that Locarno isquite busy. For the le of me I canrsquot see why.Oh, that spelling. Cregraveme brucircleacutee is described as ldquodevine. The caramel top is fine, whatrsquos under it isnrsquot. Stf with starch, no presence of vanilla grains, no quality that suggests eggs or cream, this might as well be Birdrsquos custard.Fruit in the crumble ndash apple, mango, cranberries, blueberries, pineapple apparently ndash forms an undferentiated sweet base for a topping thatrsquos moredoughy flour than gritty crumble.That pervasive smelly oven aroma has impregnated it too. A plastic high gloss shine on its orange custard reminds me of institutional catering again.Our coffee is on the house as an apology for the communication problem, but wersquove still managed to clock up a tidy bill.Itrsquos restaurants like the Locarnothat allow me to indulge myself momentarily in the otherwise ludicrous belief that restaurant reviewing canbe a chore.Food:  Value for money:  Atmosphere:  Service:

title: letters-a-u-turn-from-the-big-yin
story: However, many of those ludicrous inconsistencies and idiosyncrasies were drawn from what he often saw and exclaimed as "shortbread-tin" Scottishness and "tartan kitsch" as apparently exemplied by the likes of Harry Lauder, Andy Stewart, Jimmy Logan, Take the High Road and the White Heather Club. That these were soft targets made them no-less the bulls-eyes of Billys flourishes and, oh, along with The Big Yin, it was dficult not to roar with laughter at them, such was his delivery and imaginative flights of often-surrealistic fancies.But to many, perhaps not endowed with his keen,acerbic, sardonic sensibilities, they were hurtful parodies and pastiches of long-cherished good times, innocent, even naive memories of a world no longer current but still extant in the quiet minds eye of reminiscence.Which is why his fairly recent, ostensibly damascene, conversion to all things Scottish just sticks ever so slightly in the craw. From his knighthood from an Establishment to whom he ranks as a subject not an equal, through to his now-elevated position as Grand Marshal of New Yorks Tartan Day Parade along Manhattans Sixth Avenueit would appear that Sir Billy is now perfectly at ease with honours and commendations as a great Scot, notwithstanding his previously jaundiced views of his homeland. We all know that the past is, indeed, a foreign country and that they do things dferently there, but memories endure.Still, I suspect and hope it is nothing more than the inevitable mellowing of the years that has brought him round to a more sanguine view of Scotland and its peoples and wish him nothing but the best of health and fortune in his uncertain future.Gerard McCulloch,Moffat Wynd, Saltcoats.

title: ian-blackford-david-mundell-should-resign-if-there-is-a-no-deal-brexit
story: SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford wrote to Mr Mundell calling on him to back an extension of Article  in order to avoid the UK leaving the EU without a deal in place.The UK is due to depart on March , however there is no agreement at Westminster over a deal after Prime Minister Theresa Mayrsquos proposals were rejected.Mr Blackford suggested in his letter to the Scottish Secretary that he should publicly threaten to quit the Cabinetthe UK Government is prepared to allow a no-deal Brexit.The SNP MP also referred in his letter to a report published on Thursday by Scotlandrsquos top economic adviser which suggested that a no-deal scenario could result in a recession worse than .####### A lsquoNo Dealrsquo Brexit could mean:# % drop in GDP# -% drop in Scottish exports## Net migration turns negative#zwj# Unemployment rising by ,# Recession in Read the @scotgov Chief Economistrsquos report here: https:t.co vnaPsmPf pic QrAAblYmVmdash The SNPFebruary , Mr Blackford said: ldquoCrashing out of the EU with either Theresa Mayrsquos bad deal, or with no deal at all, is a  choice that would be disastrous for Scotland ndash destroying jobs, damaging living standards, and leaving the whole country poorer and worse off.ldquoTime is running out and the only way to prevent a bad deal for Scotland is to extend Article , and put the brakes on Brexit, to find a credible solution that protects jobs and the economy.ldquoScotland did not vote for Brexit, and we must not be dragged out of the EU against our will. It is time that the Scottish Secretary actually did his job for once by standing up for Scotlandrsquos interests.ldquoDavid Mundell must finally back SNP calls to extend Article , and make it clear that he will not serve in a UK government that is willing to impose a no-deal Brexit on Scotland.ldquoWestminster is failing Scotland. If the UK parliament continues to ignore our wishes and work against our interests, then it is clearer than ever that our interests can only be protected with independence.The Scottish Secretary has previously suggested to MPs that the best way to avoid no-deal Brexit would be to vote for the Prime Ministerrsquos deal.A UK Government source said: ldquoThis is gross hypocrisy from the SNP. The SNP lrmare doing their best to bring about a no deal, despite knowing the damage that would do to Scotland. They are only interested in their own isive, nationalist agenda, not what is best for Scotland.

title: new-bbc-scotland-channel-set-for-launch
story: Operating on an annual budget of pound million, the core hours of the channel will be between pm and am.BBC director general Tony Hall said it was the ldquobiggest single investment by the BBC in broadcast content in Scotland in over  years, when making the announcement last February.Its opening night on Sunday will begin at pm with a special performance by Scottish band Chvrches before one-off show A Night At The Theatre hosted by comedian Iain Stirling, the voice of Love Island.New programmes Getting Hitched Asian Style and The Peoplersquos News will also air on opening night, with MacDonald.Sundayrsquos core slot will be rounded off with Nae Pasaran ndash a documentary which premiered at the Glasgow Film Festivalrsquos closing gala last year.The channel aims to have a   balance title: former-priest-cancel-celibacy-vows-to-solve-churchs-culture-of-secrecy
story: Alex Walker, founder of the Advent group which helps priests thinking of leaving the church, said removing the celibacy vow would solve many of the issues around secret relationships within the church.However, allowing priests to have sex, get married and have families would open a "Pandoras box" and force the church to address issues it doesnt necessarily condone, he said.Mr Walker, who himself left the church in the s over the issue of celibacy and is now married, said: "The Catholic Church will not want to talk about numbers [of priests with children]. Even the number of priests who have resigned the ministry, or those who have requested dispensation for clerical celibacy, those numbers are not forthcoming from the Vatican."That would help with the conversation about whether celibacy is working for the majority of Catholic priests. Clearly we know it isnrsquot."Now that we have the gay debacle as well ndash there are a number of gay priests in the priesthood, and that needs to be acknowledged instead of covered up."All of this is about keeping the lid on Pandorarsquos box because once you allow priests to marry, then we get into the situation of priestsrsquo marriages breaking down, wanting orce, wanting to remarry. How can you keep the lid on that reality which the church doesnrsquot accept or condone  That is why this control of the celibacy rule for priests is key."Mr Walker explained that another reason why many priests may want to keep the fact they have children a secret is because many are ill-equipped to deal with secular le.He said: "When I left the ministry I had something like pound in my bank account. You are in a situation where you are frozen by fear [at the thought of] leaving to start a new le in the secular world."Priests are worried about security. Nine times out of  they wonrsquot have any money behind them unless theyrsquove been left a legacy from their parents, or perhaps parishioners. If they donrsquot have finances behind them then they will be reliant on the diocese renting them a property and perhaps giving them a stipend each month, which wonrsquot be a great deal."Depending on their age they have to think about employment, what do they do for a job  How do they earn their keep "It also means that they lose their status,there is still a status, for being a Roman Catholic priest. That all goes overnight as well and then they have to face up to their responsibilities which they have never really had to experience before."They have been completely sheltered in this cocoon - living in the presbytery, having their bills paid for, people treating them with deference. They would risk losing credibility amongst their own colleagues and companions too."Therersquos a lot going on there."At the end of the day, they still have fathered children and they should be the number one priority. The church should make it the number one priority for the priest also."A brief history of celibacy in the Catholic ChurchCatholic priests were not always required to be celibate, with several of the Apostles known to be married according to biblical accounts.The very first Pope, Saint Peter, was married and there are ious accounts of priests and popes throughout the ages discussing the issue of celibacy in letters and correspondence.Clement of Alexandria, a prominent theologian who died in AD, wrote: "The church fully receives the husband of one we whether he be priest or deacon or layman, supposing always that he uses his marriage blamelessly, and such a one shall be saved in the begetting of children.By AD, the first written requirement was made for those looking to join the priesthood to be celibate, and in  AD, Pope Gregory VII ruled that married priests were not allowed to say mass or carry out s.In , an ecumenical council for the Catholic church made celibacy mandatory for western clergy.In , Pope Francis said he would consider the possibility of allowing married men to join the priesthood, which is set to be discussed further this year.

title: spring-comes-early-at-scotlands-most-exotic-garden
story: Warmed by the Gulf Stream and protected from winterrsquos blast, the exotic plants of Logan Botanic Garden have always defied the harshest Scottish weather to blossom and flourish against the odds.Just  miles south of Stranraer, itrsquos where the tree fernsrsquo dainty fronds dance in the breeze, giant rhubarb leaves bigger than beach umbrellas create a tunnel to walk through and palm trees that could have come straight from a Calornian bouled thrive all year round.They can cope with the sprinkling of morning frost thatrsquos left some plants sparkling under the winter sun, says Loganrsquos curator Richard Baines. Instead, weeks of mild winter weather have taken a toll, creating confusion that has seen some plants burst into le and blossom weeks earlier than normal.ldquoLots of flowers, including some of the gardenrsquos camellia, are in full flower already, he says. ldquoThatrsquos a lot earlier than normal.One iety in particular, Mary Christian, with rich, glossy, dark green foliage and flowers of dazzling bright pink petals that hug a bouquet of delicate yellow stamen, has erupted in colour several weeks earlier than normal.ldquoItrsquos in full flower at the moment and normally that wouldnrsquot happen [for a few weeks yet], adds Baines.An early spring seemed on the cards as far back as mid-December when he spotted the first snowdrops carpeting the gardenrsquos woodland area ndash nearly two weeks earlier than expected.Throughout winter, the temperature at Logan hasnrsquot dipped below -.#c. Apart from a couple of stormy days which claimed a handful of victims, therersquos been little to send Loganrsquos exotic residents into a terribly deep sleep.ldquoI walked the garden over Christmas and counted  dferent plants in flower, Baines says. ldquoThey are definitely ahead of where they should be.ldquoOne member of staff has been here for over  years and remembers lsquoproperrsquo winters, when the whole place used to be cold and covered in frost.ldquoBut now we can grow plants which are fairly tender and can take just a little frost and they are doing fine outside.For gardeners across Scotland keeping watch for the first tentative green sprout of a crocus or bluebell, this subtle sht is not great news.A mild winter and early spring play havoc with the natural cycle of garden insects. Ladybirds may emerge from hibernation early and ready to feast on aphids only to find the cupboard bare, while a sudden cold snap could be disastrous for fragile flora.ldquoThere can be opportunity, adds Baines. ldquoMilder winters mean we can grow a wider range of plants. But the opposite is that in the last two decades you have probably had more pests and disease entering the world of horticulture than in the last two centuries.ldquoSudden oak death is pretty prominent, and one or two pests are much more prevalent because of the mild conditions.Itrsquos a clear sign ndashany were needed ndash of the battle faced by the natural world, one element of which was highlighted earlier this month when scientists warned that a global scientic review of insects had indicated they could become extinct within a century.The study, by University of Sydney, found % of all insect species are in decline. Their loss, it warned, would spark a ldquocatastrophic collapse in the worldrsquos ecosystems.ldquoQuite often therersquos a lot of mention of birds, animals and insects, but no mention of plants, he says, pointing out the risk to plantstherersquos no insects to pollinate. ldquoItrsquos always the cuddly, furry things that get the mention, but therersquos a whole ecosystem out there. When one part of the ecosystem falls down, therersquos a knock-on effect.But eveneverything in the global garden isnrsquot terribly rosy, therersquos much at Logan ndash one of four botanical gardens across Scotland that come under the umbrella of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh ndash that is, at least, blooming.Last year, more than , visitors made the journey to the Rhins of Galloway on Scotlandrsquos southwestern tip ndash closer, as the crow flies, to the Isle of Man than it is to Glasgow, and further south than Newcastle.There they breathed in the scent from more than  species of New Zealand and Australian eucalyptus at the gardenrsquos Tasmanian Creek, marvelled at -year-old tree ferns that tower four metres tall, and the curious ldquofilo pastry tree, Polylepis australis, which sheds layers of its bark in a bid to capture warm air and protect itself from the cool breezes of its native Andes mountains.In spring and summer, the mountain rhododendrons compete for attention with exotic blooms from the Canary Islands, Australia, South Africa and Chile the  species of palms ndash some over  years old ndash evoke beach le in sunny climes rather than the southwestern tip of Scotland.There are more than  species of wild flora ndash foxgloves, irises and wild grasses ndash carpeting the ground, lilies thrive on the walled gardenrsquos pond and the carbon-neutral Victorian-style greenhouse contains South American gems rarely seen in the UK.Where  could you find a driveway stretching a quarter-of-a-mile thatrsquos lined with  cabbage plants ldquoPeople are blown away by the exoticness of the place, itrsquos like an island with sea on both sides, says Baines, who was so enchanted by Logan as a child that he went on to study horticulture and follow in the footsteps of famous plant explorers like George Forrest, trekking to foreign lands in search of rare specimens.Later this year, Logan will be the focus for a series of celebrations to mark  years since it was handed to the nation.Its roots stretch much further ndash the McDouall family was granted lands in the area by John Balliol in the late th century and built a castle. Destroyed in the th century, a small stump remains within Loganrsquos walled garden.Fascination with exotic plants erupted in the th century, fuelled by explorers who ventured around the world in search of unusual species. The McDouall familyrsquos fascination with what it found and its estatersquos mild climate were a perfect match.Soon the first eucalyptus trees in Scotland were planted in the grounds, and peat bogs dug into terraces to nurture primulas.The estate was gted to the nation in November  and passed to the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh. Now, as well as being the arearsquos prime tourist attraction, itrsquos a base for horticultural study and conservation.New plants are arriving all the time. Later this year, Baines is heading on a plant expedition to Vietnam, in search of new species and to help secure the future of others.ldquoPlants are disappearing very quickly there through the impact of man, he explains.ldquoMany of these plants are very small and very fragile. A good example is a rhododendron called Kanehirae from north Vietnam."We did a survey five years ago and found the plant at Logan was the only one left in world."We propagated it, and circulated it around other botanic gardens.ldquoItrsquos not possible to undo whatrsquos been done to its native habitat, he adds. ldquoBut we can use our expertise so itrsquos not the end.

title: catholic-church-faces-mounting-pressure-to-help-traumatised-scots-children-of-priests
story: One organisation which is supporting Scots whose fathers are clerics says people are left scared and traumatised by their secretive upbringings, and feel as though the church is trying to pretend they donrsquot exist.Some have even had to sign confidentiality agreements to hide their paternal identities, according to Coping International, which advocates for children of priests.Children have also been sent to Scotland from Ireland and England as a way of keeping them hidden from parish communities which may find out about their parentage.The impact on those involved is severe and detrimental, according to campaigners, who describe their treatment and lack of acknowledgement as ldquoclerical abuse.The Catholic church in Scotland has admitted it has no idea how many Scottish priests, or those working in Scotland, have fathered children.A spokesman has also compared the situation to office workers having extramarital affairs, and said the church as an employer wouldnrsquot necessarily have to get involved.It comes after secret Vatican guidelines emerged this week for priests who father children, but the church has refused to release the documents or explain what advice they contained.Vincent Doyle, founder of support organisation Coping International, has blasted Scottish bishops for failing to get to grips with the scale of the issue, and said more needs to be done to support women and prieststhey find they are expecting a baby.Irish psychotherapist Doyle set up Coping International after he found out a priest he believed was his godfather was actually his biological dad. He said he is currently supporting several Scots between  and  whose fathers are priests, who, he said, have been left scarred by their covert parentage and are afraid to speak out.However, he stressed that the actual number of children, men and women across the globe whose fathers are Scottish priests, or who live in Scotland, is likely to be much higher.Sonflowers, a support group for women who have had relationships with priests, previously reported that it had been inundated with calls from Scottish women claiming they were having relationships with priests and in some cases were pregnant by them.The organisationrsquos founder said in  she had hoped to set up a specically Scottish group to deal with the influx of calls but faced opposition to even advertising her service in churches or bulletins across the country.Doyle said: ldquoWe are supporting eight Scottish people. Eight may seem like a small number to many, but for those eight people their lives have been hugely affected.ldquoThey have been hidden, they have had confidentiality agreements too. They are scared.ldquoWe have one Scottish woman we are working with who was fathered by an Irish priest. They moved to Scotland and hid her there and she has hidden ever since. She doesnrsquot know what to do or how to bring it up.ldquoThese people are terried. One guy I know has psychosis, hersquos on the verge of schizophrenia.ldquoWe have a lot of kids also from Ireland and England sent to Scotland, who were adopted but now through things like ancestry and DNA matching sites they are finding out their roots and what actually happened.ldquoThere are around  priests in Scotland at the minute, but how many men have been ordained in Scotland or how many Scottish men have been missionary priests over the last  years  That is where the real question is.ldquoWhen you take that into consideration,only % of those priests fathered children, yoursquore talking about a surprising number.ldquoOn a global level, we know about , children in this position and that is only the ones we know about, itrsquos a hugely conservative estimate.A Catholic church spokesman told The Herald on Sunday there was no evidence of ldquosignicant numbers of children fathered by priests in Scotland, and compared priests having relationships to an office worker having an extramarital affair with a colleague.He said in both scenarios, vows would have been broken but it would not necessarily be the responsibility of the employer to get involved.When pressed, he admitted the church had no idea of the numbers and he had only heard of one such case before, but insisted that Scottish bishops would support prieststhey came to them to ask for help.The spokesman said: ldquoIn the case of a priest who has fathered a child, it is not possible to rule out any possible responses to these situations.ldquoA decision to remain or leave the priesthood would be made on its merits in each case.ldquoThere are no central records of such cases and while the church would not necessarily be aware of them, there is no suggestion of signicant numbers in this country.He also said there had been several priests who had left the priesthood to pursue relationships, and in his view there was no stigma around the issue.He said: ldquoIf a priest was to say to his bishop that he had fathered a child and, whether he wanted help to leave the priesthood and set up as a father or to remain in the priesthood but be able to support the child, the church would do whatever they could to support either of those options.ldquoEvery year a number [of priests] leave to get married. One left from Glasgow last year, for example. In the past that would have been seen as much more scandalous and a stigma. The view now is that the church is grateful for the service that you have given.Doyle has criticised the remarks and called for the church in Scotland to take the lead in finding and supporting people fathered by priests, and to understand why many priests do not disclose they have children.He said: ldquoI absolutely condemn the use of that world lsquosignicantrsquo in any regard. This is clerical abuse. If there are only five or  children in Scotland, so what  Quantity never should come in to pastoral care.ldquoIn order for this issue to be addressed we have to do away with moralistic audacious statements and look at this practically and also empower the woman. If you empower the mother and say lsquoyou are far from alone, you donrsquot need to be afraidrsquo, it would help, instead of the woman being told they are the only person in Scotland who is in this situation, and they must keep quiet in order for the priest to be able to support them and not lose their job.ldquoI would go back to the Catholic bishops in Scotland and ask them what constitutes a signicant number. We are working with eight people ndash is that insignicant  I donrsquot know the full number of children of priests in Scotland, but neither do the bishops.ldquoThe Catholic church should be willing to bend over backwards for one child so this whole thing of lsquosignicancersquo is hugely disrespectful, harmful and what they are trying to do is make this inauthentic.ldquoThere are children of priests the same as there are children of plumbers, fishermen, hairdressers ... they are out there.ldquoAnd it is never going to stop. Unless they stop ordaining heterosexual males it will happen. They canrsquot quanty it and they canrsquot address it.ldquoThe church have tried to dismiss child sexual abuse initially by saying its unquantiable, itrsquos the same thing.If you have been affected by this story please contact Hannah Rodgerathannah.rodger@heraldandtimes

title: in-pictures-homes-transformed-into-magnificent-galleries-at-window-wanderland
story: An annual tradition, locals decorated their windows with colourful, ornate designs.One home even renamed itself the Bungo Jukebox, decorating every window with a musical theme.Another featured a controversial message about the recent Glasgow School of Art fire.Hundreds walked the streets and marvelled at the fantastic displays, while others attended film screenings at a pop-up cinema.The Pollywood community cinema showed Rear Window by Alfred Hitchcock along with several other flicks throughout the evening.

title: rab-mcneil-concentrate-on-your-allotment-jeremy-theres-plenty-of-horse-manure-in-parliament
story: All I know is that centre parties are always rubbish and are only supported by ditherers who canrsquot make up their mind between left and right, and who fall for all the tripe about a ldquonew politics espoused by people steeped in the old politics and, more importantly, desperate to keep their seats.No, I am more interested in the much-reported fact that when the splitters were preparing to leave his party, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn went down to his allotment to lt some tatties. Irsquom quite sure that, in many ways, Jeremy would be a disaster for the country ndash as, to be fair, would they all ndash but there are some things I canrsquot help liking about the man.Hersquos done good work in ing the otherwise pointless party to its socialist roots .Anyway, as news of the allotment scandal broke, right-wing papers screamed that hersquod ldquolost the plot and even that he was ldquoin a hole. Disgraceful. But, oddly enough, that very same day, one such publication coincidentally ran another story about GPs prescribing allotments to patients suffering from stress or heart scares or loneliness.Irsquom not sure how it benefits the latter, unless one is expected to talk to onersquos plants. I have tried this, and the downside is that it is frankly a one-sided conversation. Itrsquos pretty much the same with the garden birds, though sometimes they do tweet back and, once, Irsquom sure I heard a tit say, ldquoShut up, beardie!However, I do back the idea of allotments being good for the soul. The happiest times of my le coincided with having allotments. During one particular period, I wrote in the morning, tended my allotment in the afternoon, and sorted mail for the GPO in the evenings, back in the days when I could truly claim to be a man of letters.I was poor but as happy as Larry, whoever he is, and remembered that Karl Marx had pretty much described such a le under communism in his famous book, ldquoDas Allotments. A particularly pleasant memory is of spreading rotten seaweed on the soil and a blackbird being so transported with delight that, after scoffing his fill of wee microbes on the maritime manure, he came and sat and warbled on the toe of my boot as I lay back contented with my labours.Alas, every time it came time for cultivation, I had to abandon the plot, as I am one of those fellows who can never settle and is always moving on, usually with disastrous consequences.In my lectures to young people about le, I always tell them:. Do not stand out from the crowd.. Donrsquot go anywhere. I didnrsquot get where I am todayby going anywhere, and. As for crowds, yoursquore best not getting involved with them at all.The same goes for political parties. Therersquos a growing feeling that such a system of agglomerated ndash and that really, inexplicably feels like the right word ndash iniduals is done. I never understood it anyway, particularly having a slate of policies that you had to agree with in full: ldquoI am pro-gay rights therefore I am anti-nuclear.My advice to Jeremy is to spend more time on his allotment and less time in Parliament. There are enough vegetables already in the latter. And the place is filled to the rafters with manure.If Ikea made history ...ITrsquoS so common for historians to rewrite history these days that they should probably be described as rehistorians.Itrsquos terribly tedious, as it overturns the ldquotruths we were taught as nippers, making us doubt everything we are told and take up careers in journalism.However, I must say I was taken with the idea of a ldquoNeolithic Ikea, which suggested that folks in the Flintstone Era waddled around chaotic quarries and chose large items to take home.This, we are told, is what happened at yonder Stonehenge, suggesting that the whole thing was a kind of flatpack assembled at home on the Salisbury Plain by men reading instructions consisting largely of illustrations, as seen in the Lascaux caves .Maybe that explains why the stones are all wonky and there are bits missing. Mind you, itrsquos not known how they got the stones from Neolithikea back up the road.As many of you who have tried cramming a flatpack wardrobe into a Nissan Micra will have discovered, this is by far the worst part of the whole business.The best job on Middle EarthI HAVE discovered the dream job: sitting in a bunker near LA, writing the script for Amazonrsquos planned Lord of the Rings prequel.Way back in the last century, Hollywood used to hire writers to work in little rooms in special writersrsquo blocksand just come up with ideas and scripts. Most of it never amounted to anything, and nor was much expected, but they were paid vast salaries to tootle away at their typewriters.The incomparable PG Wodehouse was one such, but I think he found it rather dull and unfulfilling, I wouldnrsquot. Me! Me! Irsquoll do that.One problem at the Tolkien writing bunker is that the writers are kept under lock and key, to stop any script leaks getting out. I think the writers are let out from time to time, and itrsquos suggested that itrsquos as much to keep spies out as scribblers in.Added to which, I bet the foodrsquos good and the rewards spectacular. Please: me! I know the dference between the Vanyar and the Noldor elves. I know Darth Vaderrsquos the bad guy. Therersquos also a Wookie, right

title: garfield-phones-chaplin-headlines-smart-fridges-and-the-nearly-greatest-its-almost-worth-not-waving-a-flag-about
story: Itrsquos a mystery of the deep which has baffled the finest French maritime scientists and climatologists for more than  years. Where do these Garfield telephones which keep being washed up on the coast of Brittany come from One theory is that a container of them fell overboard in the Channel some time in the s and currents have pushed them southwards since. However, such a loss has never been reported to the maritime authorities, which may not be unusual as hundreds of containers slip overboard each year, but as owners are responsible for recovery costs they often donrsquot admit to it.Containers go straight down to the seabed and break open over time, so there will be thousands of them down there with goodness knows what inside. Lord Lucan possibly.These troublesome and persistent yellow and black Garfields, moulded as the cartoon character, are made of apparently indestructible plastic and they donrsquot float, so they have inched ndash or millimetred ndash towards France, pushed by the currents for three decades to the beaches. And, no, they donrsquot still work.Itrsquos possible ndash my theory ndash that the washed-up ones are pirate copies of the real thing, given therersquos no serial number, stamp or other identier on them. Certainly another damaging,rather quirky, reminder of the plastic pollution in our oceans and seas.Headline news on your doorstepLike all good, lasting myths the one about the Press And Journal and the Titanic ndash ldquoAberdeen man drowns at sea ndash has been impossible to scotch, even after more than  years ... and even although it isnrsquot strictly, or even a little, accurate. In fact, the headline in the Aberdeen Daily Journal, as it then was, blandly stated: ldquoAberdeen people on the Titanic. But the myth will never perish.I can vouch, however, that when commemorating Charlie Chaplin the headlinesaid ldquoNairn was famous comedianrsquos favourite holiday resort. I was in Nairn at the time, doorstepping a paedophile priest, so I swear itrsquos true.Great headlines are immortal. A favourite of mine, long ago fromwhen it was worth reading, was ldquoQueen in riot at Palace. Sadly not about Her Maj and Phil having a bust-up over his wayward driving, but Scottish forward Gerry Queen in a punch-up at Crystal Palace. Then therersquos ldquoSuper Caley go ballistic Celtic are atrocious.In the spirit of the PJ and Titanic, here are a few competitors from the Oldham Evening Chronicle, which died in August ndash the paper, not the headlines ndash but has now been resuscitated in an online version. ldquoCat saves owners as fire grips armchair, ldquoBraking bus shakes children, but the real successor to the loon drowning, or not, in the Atlantic surely is ldquo die in Bay blaze but Oldham man is safe.The new digital version its trying hard. ldquoOldham woman hit by tram at Oldham Mumps, it reported during the week. The tram is said to be recovering.Love in a cold climateIf yoursquore looking for a partner and yoursquore too hip, old, or ugly to try Tinder or Grindr then therersquos a cool new dating app that has just launched. Cool  Itrsquos pure Baltic.It has the same swipe technology used by other sites but this one shows pictures of the contents of your fridge. Apparently, you can find a love matchall you have in the icebox is out-of-date milk, the remains of an Indian takeaway and a couple of cans of beer. Well, perhaps not. It didnrsquot work for me.This is, of course, a pretty pathetic, publicity-seeking wheeze by Samsung to sell its Family Hub fridges, which are wi-connected and come with an internal camera. Oh, and a price tag of around pound,. The company claims that you can tell a lot about the personality of someone by judging the contents of their fridge, which, unfortunately in my case, may be true.But why anyone would want to reveal their unpleasant secret, selfie-ing their mouldy comestibles while standing in the kitchen, and organising their le on the touchscreen of a fridge large enough to house Kathy Bates, defeats me.When he became kingIt will be  years tomorrow that arguably the greatest sportsman of our times, the then Cassius Clay, aged , beat world heavyweight champion Sonny Liston, whose guts gave out and he retired on his stool at the start of the seventh round. In the run-up to the fight, where he was a - outsider, pundits chortled when Clay declared: ldquoI was born to be great. I am great and I will be greater ndash the greatest.Three years later, having proved it, and now Muhammad Ali, he was stripped of the title in his prime for refusing conscription to the Vietnam war, famously saying: ldquoMan, I ainrsquot got no quarrel with them Viet Cong, No Viet Cong ever called me a n****r. He was out of boxing for four-and-a-half years before his all-conquering .Will EU or wonrsquot EU We may or may not leave the EU at the end of next month but, according to a recent survey, one-third of the people in France and Germany already think we have gone. Perhaps wishful thinking  It is almost certain that we wonrsquot be participating in the May European elections and, according to surveys carried out in all  remaining countries, the far right is going to benefit from British absence.The far-right ENF groupwill be the main beneficiary, going from  seats to . This grouping hosts Marine Le Penrsquos National Rally party and the Italian League party of Matteo Salvini, up from six seats to .A VEXED QUESTIONUntil last week I didnrsquot know what a vexillologist was , or that there was a charity called the Flag Institute, which manages the UK Flag Registry. Nor did I know that East Lothian had recently had its flag design registered ndash it looks like a Lion Rampant in a box being struck by thunderbolts. Or the stushie over the Sutherland one. The original design, which was a swooping eagle in red and yellow against the same colours, counterchanged, in the background, roused the ire of the locals, with one of the objectors claiming in evoked communism .The Lord Lyon, who seems to have a say in these things, halted the process and a design was finally chosen, after a public vote. The final version looks like the kind of number stormtroopers wear on their arms, but apparently it evokes sunrises and sunsets ndash perhaps,yoursquove been poked in the eye with a flagpole. Thatrsquos a lot of not knowing by me to unfurl.All of which leads to the, perhaps unsurprising, news that the sales of Union Jacks have gone up  per cent in the last few months. I like the Banksy quote from his work, Wall And Piece: ldquoPeople who enjoy waving flags donrsquot deserve to have one.

title: cool-list-the-best-scottish-railway-journeys
story: Edinburgh to AberdourThink ldquotrains and ldquoScotland then let your mind come to rest on the third image that comes to you. OK, so right now yoursquore probably seeing the information board at Glasgow Queen Street with the words ldquocancelled and ldquodelayed sprinkled across it, so letrsquos skip that and try for the fourth image which, pun intended, is bound to be the Forth Bridge.Nothing  evokes the romance of rail travel quite like this wonder of Victorian engineering, and for a relatively modest fee ndash aticket from Edinburgh Waverley to Inverkeithing, the first stop on the north side of the estuary ndash you can enjoy not one but two trips across it.However, an even better idea is to stay on until Aberdour, where you can disembark at one of Scotlandrsquos prettiest stations, walk the few yards to one of its most interesting castlesand then stroll downhill to the sandy town beach. Glasgow to MallaigProperly referred to as the West Highland Line, this beguiling stretch of rail is now better known to millennials as the Harry Potter Line thanks to the spectacular Glenfinnan Viaduct which the Hogwarts Express crosses in the blockbuster films. As the train chugs its way northwest from Glasgow there are glimpses of Ben Nevis, Loch Shiel and Loch Eilt, and you may even catch sight of the isles of Rum, Eigg, Muck and Canna.The line crosses desolate Rannoch Moor and passes through Corrour, the highest mainline station in the UK, but it also serves coastal Arisaig, where anyone disembarking can enjoy some of the whitest sands in the world.The entire line is regularly voted one of the most scenic on the planet so itrsquos already deserving of its place in the Cool List, butyou want to go the whole Hogwarts then hop on board The Jacobite, the steam-hauled train which runs between Fort William and Mallaig. Leadhills to WanlockheadIf geographical trivia is your specialist subject at the local pub quiz then you donrsquot need telling that Wanlockhead is Scotlandrsquos highest village or that itrsquos located not in the Highlands but in the Lowther Hills in Dumfries and Gallowayrsquos Southern Uplands. If all that comes as news to you and you fancy a visit, donrsquot miss this treat. The railway is a narrow gauge and runs along the track bed of what was once a branch line on the Caledonian Railway to Wanlockhead from nearby Elvanfoot.It closed in  and shortly afterwards the lead mines it served were mothballed, so now the railway mostly pulls tourists along the kilometre or so between the two villages. Naturally, Wanlockhead also boasts Scotlandrsquos highest pub, the perfect place to read Robert Burnsrsquos poem Pegasus At Wanlockhead, written over a dram in another local hostelry as he waited for the horse of that name to have a shoe tended to by the village blacksmith. Inverness to WickKnown as the Far North Line for obvious reasons, this four-and-a-half-hour, -mile journey sees the train follow the coast for much of the way. Among the stops is one practically at the gates of the magnicent Dunrobin Castle, completed in the s at the behest of the owner who quite fancied having his own railway line. It required the say-so of Parliament but given that the owner was the Duke of Sutherland, the permissions werenrsquot too hard to get.Other highlights include Skibo Castle, Foulis Castle, the atmospheric peat bogsand the distilleries of Teaninich, Dalmore, Balblair, Whyte  Mackay , Glenmorangie , and, in Wick itself, Pulteney . Inverness to Kyle of LochalshIf yoursquore heading for Skye from the capital of the Highlands, then the so-called Kyle Line is the only way to travel.
