The line runs along the Beauly Firth, through Dingwall and on past villages such as Achnashellach, Achnasheen, Lochcarron and picturesque Plockton, where much-loved BBC drama Hamish Macbeth was filmed. Naturally there are great views of Skye itself at the end of the line but along the way yoursquoll also see the Torridon Peaks, Ben Wyvis, Loch Luichart and Loch Carron as well as some rugged Highland scenery. Aviemore to BroomhillThe route isnrsquot so much the treat here as the train itself because itrsquos on these  miles of restored track from the original Highland Railway Line that the Strathspey Steam Railway has run since it was brought back to le by a group of enthusiasts in . It runs between Aviemore stationrsquos  three and Broomhillrsquos Glenbogle station via Boat of Garten and when yoursquore not looking out of the window at the sceneryyoursquoll be looking around the old-style carriages or even down at your plate ndash the service offers all manner of dining experiences, from light lunches and afternoon teas to formal evening meals. Dufftown to KeithThis -mile line links the Moray towns of Keith and Dufftown, the self-styled ldquoWhisky Capital of the World . Predictably the line itself, once part of the Aberdeen to Elgin line, is known now as the Whisky Line and also bills itself the UKrsquos most northerly ldquoheritage railway. The rolling stock includes old commuter carriages from the s and s, and a dining coach which used to be part of the British Rail InterCity stock, but which has been repainted and renamed Spirit Of Dufftown. The line is closed for the winter and reopens on April . Borsquoness to Manuel JunctionOne of Scotlandrsquos most popular heritage railways, the Borsquoness and Kinneil Railway runs five miles between Borsquoness near Falkirk and Manuel Junction, via Kinneil and Birkhill. The views are pretty enough but again itrsquos the rolling stock which is the star.Among the favourites are  Neilson Reid locomotive Lord Roberts, which has been painted Thomas The Tank Engine blue, a set of s coaches in whatrsquos known as a ldquoblood and custard livery, and a pair of Caledonian coaches built in . Borsquoness is also home to the Museum of Scottish Railways, which houses historic locomotives, carriages, cranes, wagonsas well as shunting units, motorised trolleys and all manner of objects and archive stuff. Edinburgh to TweedbankThe Borders line, closed in  as part of the infamous Beeching cuts, reopened with no little fanfare in September  and reconnected the capital with the Borders towns of Galashiels and Melroseas well as Midlothian towns such as Dalkeith, Newtongrange and Gorebridge. The scenery is pleasant enough ndash go to the Highlandsyou want mountains and lochs ndash but the appeal of the Borders Railway, as itrsquos now known, lies in its ality and its historical importance: its rebirth brought a new dynamism and opportunity to a part of the country too often overlooked, and signicant numbers of tourists as well. Book lovers in particular have good reason to take the trip. Where  can you take a train which starts from a station named after a famous novel ndash Waverley, by Sir Walter Scott ndash and terminates close to the authorrsquos home, in this case Abbotsford, near Melrose  Milton of Crathes to Birkenbaud CrossingItrsquos only a mile of track along the now-disused Ballater to Aberdeen line, but as the name suggests the Royal Deeside Railway is steeped in history, thanks to the fact that for over a century, until its closure in , it was used by the royal family travelling to Ballater and from there to nearby Balmoral Castle. It was even used by ill-fated Russian tsar Nicholas II when he visited in .The original Crathes Castle station was built initially for the private use of the Laird of Crathes, and only later was the public allowed to use it. The Milton of Crathes station features a Victorian building but it came originally from Oldmeldrum and was sold to the Royal Deeside Railway for pound then transported to its new home in carefully labelled sections.The line has both steam- and diesel-hauled trains and among the former is the Thomas The Tank Engine-style Salmon. A sombre coda: the engine was named in commemoration of HMS Salmon, a submarine lost with all hands in . The line is closed for the winter and will reopen at Easter.How the Borders Railway creates a new future for Scotlands "forgotten" regionTravel: the West Highland Line

title: scotlands-money-are-we-spending-it-properly
story: Itrsquos two days before the Budget and Derek Mackay, Scotlandrsquos Finance Secretary, is sitting in his spartan ministerial office robustly defending his spending plans ndash while dealing with a nasty cold.Hersquos a man facing an almost impossible array of demands. Some of the brightest minds, and biggest voices, are calling for him to pull to the left, pull to the right, protect the poor, and boost business ndash all at the same time. Mackay ndash self-contained, confident and smartly dressed ndash may see himself as a steady pair of hands, but hersquod need the skill of a juggler to make everyone happy.At its heart, the Budget is redistributive ndash taking from the rich to provide services for the poor by widening the gap between how much higher earners pay in income tax in Scotland compared with the rest of the UK. Mackay has frozen the higher rate threshold at pound, in Scotland, while it will go up to pound, in the rest of the UK. However, everyone earning under pound, ndash % of taxpayers ndash will end up paying less income tax than in the rest of the UK.The spending plans also provide extra money for education , health , and infrastructure , and give new powers to councils to introduce a workplace car parking tax and a tourist tax. Local authorities get an extra poundm and can also increase council tax by up to .% rather than %.But what do the people who spend their lives studying the Scottish economy make of the Budget  Does the way Scotland spends its money work  Where could money be spent better  And what ideas might change the game when it comes to Scotland and out public services Some of the leading lights in Scottish public le give their views.PROFESSOR RONALD MACDONALDECONOMIST WITH THE ADAM SMITH BUSINESS SCHOOL AT GLASGOW UNIVERSITYRonnie MacDonald is happy to pay more tax, but he isnrsquot so happy with the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach to balancing the books. ldquoThe focus seems to be too much on spending ndash there isnrsquot so much emphasis on growing the economy, he says.About half the revenue raised comes from taxes, he says, and our ldquoeconomy is very skewed towards oil ndash a commodity in price decline. ldquoItrsquos a dangerous strategy for the long-term sustainability of public spending, MacDonald says.With limited borrowing powers, the Government has a choice between "growing the economy or spending less". The Government is following a Nordic-style model of public spending, he says.However, ldquothese Nordic countries grew their economies before making spending changes, we seem to be doing it the other way around.ldquoI think wersquoll ultimately have to cut spending, he adds. ldquoYou either prioritise and have a leaner mix now, or yoursquore forced to do it in the future ndash you could face much worse cuts in the future.Higher taxes in Scotland ldquomay well put off foreign firms thinking of investing in Scotland, he says. ldquoIf Irsquom a US-based company thinking of Scotland or the north of England, Irsquom going to go where the tax regime is more favourable to my employees. All in all itrsquos quite a dangerous game theyrsquore playing.Macdonald suggests a ldquorealignment from spending ldquotowards lowering business rates to encourage growth.A more erse economy would grow more quickly, says MacDonald, and provide the money needed for the ldquopublic provision the SNP wants to offer. Manufacturing around le sciences and new technology is one way forward.MacDonald suggests Scotland should follow the path of Australia ndash currently blazing a trail with the solar production of renewable hydrogen as a green energy source. Renewable hydrogen, says MacDonald, can be stored and shipped in liquid form. Given Scotlandrsquos wind and waves, wersquod be in a perfect position to exploit the new technology in the era of climate change.ldquoIt could be revolutionary, MacDonald says. ldquoIt could be as important as the discovery of oil ... it could lead to the reindustrialisation of Scotland.If the Government used public money to invest in the new technology ldquoit could create a sovereign wealth fund as the Norwegians did to use oil to pay for services.DAVE MOXHAMSTUC DEPUTY GENERAL SECRETARYldquoThe Budget is incredibly timid, says Moxham. ldquoWith the current ambition of a little bit more tax on middle- to higher-income earners, itrsquos quite impossible to fund the public services we need without the recognition that people on median and above incomes are going to have to pay more in taxation."We canrsquot pretend therersquos any mechanism for funding public services which doesnrsquot have that sort of ambition.ldquoItrsquos not enough to constantly use a Conservative Government as a comparator and say wersquore being slightly more progressive. Any party which aspires to say Scotland would be dferent under independence needs to be showing more now about what their commitment is to social justice.The STUC, says Moxham, would be ldquocomfortable with everyone above median income ndash about pound, ndash paying an extra penny in tax. ldquoThatrsquos small change. Itrsquos hardly bank-breaking, he adds.Spending needs to get smarter and more local too, Moxham says. Councils and council staff need more say in spending ndash as they understand the problems. ldquoTherersquos too much centralisation and not enough devolution to local authorities, he adds.He cites hospitals improving heart failure response times because ldquothe porters helped design the system of getting someone from the front steps to the operating theatre.ldquoWersquove had lots of reorganisation of the delivery of public services but these have tended to be executive-led, he says. Whatrsquos needed is getting the people who deliver the services ndash carers, nurses, teachers ndash to help design services. ldquoThe person who best knows how to organise a home care service is probably the home carer on the ground.The big idea that the STUC is investigating is a ldquouniversal basic infrastructure ndash where everyone has the guaranteed right to decent transport, housing, clinics and schools. Public spending priorities would be re-engineered around making sure every citizen had the basic infrastructure for a decent le.Small business bonus schemes are in the STUCrsquos sights. ldquoWe need a completely new approach to business tax giveaways, says Moxham. Investing in specic high-street regeneration schemes ldquois a far better way to rebuild our local high streets than the current approach where someone may need the boost, but others are using it to fund a second car.TRACY BLACKDIRECTOR OF CBI SCOTLANDIF the Government stimulates the white heat of technology it can fill its coffers with tax pounds and use the money to spend on the public services it wants ndash thatrsquos essentially Blackrsquos view.A no-deal Brexit could cost Scotland poundbn a year by , she says, and our demographics are going against us with a rapidly ageing population, so we need to start spending as smartly as we can. AI and automation could reduce costs. The elderly donrsquot have to travel to hospital when their blood pressure could be checked by remote monitoring. Investment in smart-ticketing and autonomous vehicles could help the high street.Glasgow may be a G hub, but connectivity needs improved across the country, as does infrastructure, Black says, so ldquowe get goods and people moving around more effectively.One big idea that Black is promoting is using national data to change how we spend public money. Data on the economy and population could be used by business ldquoto come up with really creative solutions around transport and health.The Scottish Government has done well so far supporting science and technology in business. Black says our pharma manufacturing sector is one of the most advanced in the world ndash itrsquos now the second-biggest spender on research and development, exports poundm in products, and has seen jobs rise by .%. The Medicines Manufacturing Innovation Centre in Renfrewshire was l funded by the Government and industry.Itrsquos this close working relationship between Government and industry that Black wants more of ndash but she feels there are ldquomixed messages when it comes to income tax, parking levies and the tourist tax. ldquoNone of these on their own are particularly crippling, but you put the whole package together and what sort of signal does that put out to inward investors PROFESSOR GRAEME ROYDIRECTOR OF THE FRASER OF ALLANDER INSTITUTE"THE debate around public spending collapses down into short-term political sound bites rather than more intelligent conversations," says Roy. "We see that every week at First Ministerrsquos Questions and in every manesto that every party produces."Parties obsess on issues like ", more nurses or , extra police officers" when they should be looking at outcomes ndash like extending le expectancy or making streets safer. It may be that spending more money on housing rather than nurses will improve le expectancy. Preventative measures ndash that improve health or cut crime ndash will save money in the long run."Simple metrics donrsquot do anything for the long-term delivery of better value for public services," Roy says. "Therersquos a fixation on targets and numbers when the evidence is that you should be bolder."He adds: "If wersquore thinking about long-term sustainability of public services what we need to do is reduce demand, not just keep increasing supply."Such a quantum sht in how we look at public spending would require political courage. Politicians are locked in short election cycles, while long-term preventative policies might take decades to show fruit, Roy says. Closing a hospital because it makes more sense to spend the money on nutrition for the young could lose a government an election, even though  years from now it might have improved health."Some of the delivery of public services is simply not going to be sustainable in the long run," Roy says. "Wersquove played with numbers where we think that on current projections NHS spending will within the next two or three years be pretty much % of the Scottish Budget. This will mean every other area in the public sector has to be squeezed ndash thatrsquos the sort of thing which I think will start to force more radical thoughts on how we deliver public services."JOHN DICKIEDIRECTOR, CHILD POVERTY ACTION GROUPDickie is clear that Scotlandrsquos public spending does not match the ambition of the Government when it comes to tackling child poverty. Targets have been set that less than % of children should be living in poverty by .With currently one in four Scots children in poverty ndash thatrsquos about , ndash to reach that target, says Dickie, "we need a substantial rethink of how we raise revenue and allocate resources to make sure those families on the lowest incomes can give children a decent start in le". Estimates show that one in three children could be in poverty within a few years.Dickie wants an "income supplement" to lt family finances to levels above the poverty line. The government is committed to introducing an income supplement by  ndash however, it hasnrsquot said how that will be delivered or how much it will be.The supplement needs brought in now, Dickie says. "Families canrsquot wait until ." He applauds policies like best start grants for families, and improvements in school clothing grants but says "none of this is on the scale to have the kind of substantive long-term impact to really change the trajectory of child poverty".Dickie would also like to see the Scottish Government act to top up child benefit by around pound, following cuts by the UK Government.Not tackling child poverty is a drain on the economy ndash with children more likely to get involved in crime, have poor health, and fewer job prospects. "The government needs to act with urgency," Dickie says. It needs to "recognise the value of the next generation" and invest.DEREK MITCHELLCHIEF EXECUTIVE, CITIZENS ADVICE SCOTLANDWHEN there are families going to foodbanks and receiving "cold bags" of shopping because their gas and electricity has been cut off ndash when % of people in "food poverty" are working ndash then for Mitchell "that doesnrsquot paint a picture of a society where everything is wonderful and great"."The simple matter is," he says, "that things are very dficult for lots of people and that doesnrsquot show any sign of abating."Public resources need to go to those most in need, Mitchell says. "Poor people donrsquot have a voice. Wersquove a debate at a political level. We talk about interest rates and mortgage rates, we donrsquot talk about household debt."Put simply: wersquore looking at things through the wrong end of the telescope. Get tougher with payday loan companies, force employers to pay decent wages, increase the funeral expense allowance, prioritise affordable rent ndash these are the levers of Government Mitchell wants to see pulled.DEREK MACKAYSCOTTISH FINANCE SECRETARYMACKAYrsquoS childhood shaped his politics. This is a man who didnrsquot grow up easy ndash raised in a council house, he even spent time in a homeless unit after a family break-up. He puts his le lessons into his policies ndash beliefs like ldquothe importance of community, kindness, treating others as you would be treated yourself.ldquoIrsquom very aware of chaotic lestyles, lack of opportunities, intergenerational poverty, he says. Mackay says he struck it lucky by entering politics and getting elected. It changed the direction of his le.Hersquos got a slick command of his portfolio and can rattle off statistics at a dizzying rate ndash but his Budget is assailed from all sides: itrsquos either a hit on the middle classes or it isnrsquot doing enough for the poor.Criticism doesnrsquot faze Mackay though ndash only once does he falter, and even then momentarily, when asked why the SNP needed the Greens to push them in a more progressive direction over policies like the parking levy.In his eyes, the Budget is about stability in the face of ldquocalamity at Westminster sustainability of public services, and stimulus for the economy.Mackay says preventative measures are built in when it comes to public health and early years ndash and the economy of the future is being looked after in terms of innovation on data and infrastructure. Direct investment in Scotland is second only to London, and research and development is at record levels. He makes much of new figures showing unemployment is at an all-time low.However, therersquos only so much the Government can do given the limited range of powers granted to a devolved administration, he says. ldquoWe can grow the economy as an independent countrywe have control of levers like immigration policy, and over a wider basket of taxation powers.Mackay described his current Budget as ldquofair and progressive in that it takes ldquoa bit more from the highest earning section of society. In the next financial year, he says, ldquo% of taxpayers will pay less tax, not more, on their current incomes, and itrsquos only those on or above pound, who will pay more.Itrsquos a ldquobalanced and moderate approach, he thinks. ldquoWersquore building a social security system with a dferent philosophy around dignity and respect, he said, while claiming the UK Government was in a ldquorace to the bottom on tax.While Mackay attempts to create a more progressive Budget, he insists hersquos also trying to remain pro-business as he believes ldquothe best social policy is employment. He dismissed claims of ldquoclass war in his Budget.ldquoIf we donrsquot invest in society and have the necessary safeguards for all then everyone pays for societal failure ndash business and taxpayers pay for this with prisons and unemployment, he says, adding that he believes his Budget presents a ldquopretty good deal.Reformation of council tax is likely to dominate the political discussion soon with plans for cross-party talks to find an alternative. ldquoIf we can find the consensus that could adequately and safety replace it then wersquoll support that, Mackay says. Legislation could be prepared in this Parliament for implementation in the next.Come the end of this Parliament, the country will also be heading towards the time for a review of the ldquofiscal framework set out by the Smith Commission and Scotland Act, which will mean the Government can ask for more powers from Westminster.Mackay admits such an ask wonrsquot be easy as ldquoWestminster concedes nothing without challenge and pressure.

title: david-pratt-just-what-is-going-on-in-haiti
story: THERE is nothing like a coup drsquoetat to bring out the headcase and the hedonist in people.When I first visited Haiti back in , aside from the countryrsquos legions of poor, it seemed almost entirely inhabited by these two species of inidual.The capital Port-au-Prince was in meltdown back then, the cityrsquos ramshackle streets a labyrinth of barricades and blazing tyres, looters, shooters and partygoers.President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was in the process of being deposed from power. In the space of a few weeks, I would watch those same "bouleds" once consumed by violence and littered with corpses turn into one giant carnival as thousands crammed to dance the night away to Haitian and Caribbean music.Everywhere around the national palace that had been Aristidersquos lair of power, giant floats drted by while women in flamingo pink dresses, and voodoo priests, partied against the pure white backdrop of the whitewashed palace facade that dazzled in the nighttime dark like an edice of snow.There are few countries in the world that Irsquove been to quite like Haiti. Even fewer that have seen so much turmoil and destruction. It really does beggar belief that such a place exists an hour-and-a-halfrsquos flight from glittering Miami, and less than three hours from New York City. As the books and experts will attest to, Haiti is the poorest country in the Western hemisphere and the worldrsquos least developed outside of Africa ndash and believe me does it show.At night in the cityrsquos Marche en Fer or Iron Market district, crushing poverty forces sex workers, some little more than children, onto the filthy fire-lit streets.This is a two-tier nation that rises from the slums of Cite Soleil and Saint Martin, where hundreds of thousands cram into reclaimed swampland and cemeteries.So congested is it here that people I met said that ldquosht sleeping is common.With many single cupboard-sized rooms too small to house an entire family at any one time, people have been known to bed down on a rota basis, four hours inside and four hours in the alleyways outside.It might be a short distance as the crow flies in Port-au-Prince, but these teeming, humid slums are a world apart from the cool hills above where the wealthy live in the gated communities of Petionville, with their fine restaurants catering to a very dferent side of Haitian le.Right there in that very juxtaposition Haitirsquos inequality lies encapsulated. A chasm between haves and have-nots that for decades has led to political instability and violence which these past weeks has once again reared up and gripped the country.ldquoAfter each election, we are deeper and deeper in a crisis. People are living day-by-day ... If you donrsquot resolve the situation, yoursquoll have another uprising, warned Jean Clarens Renois, a former journalist and presidential candidate last week as street protests in the country intensied.For the last two weeks now, almost unnoticed by the international media, thousands of Haitians have taken to the streets, asking for US-backed president Jovenel Moise and his government to resign. Writing in the New York Times a few months ago, Jake Johnston, an international associate at the Centre for Economic and Policy Research in Washington and an expert on Haiti, told the story of what sparked the current round of unrest.ldquoIt started with a few keystrokes in a living room in Montreal, he wrote.ldquoGilbert Mirambeau Jr, a Haitian filmmaker and writer, took to Twitter on August  to post a photo of himself, blindfolded, holding a piece of cardboard with a simple question written on it in Haitirsquos Creole: ldquoKot Kob Petwo Karibe a    ndash Where is the Petrocaribe money   As Johnston went on to explain in the article, just a few days after Mirambeaursquos tweet, an informal group of young Haitians organised on social media using the hashtag #PetroCaribeChallenge and since then Haitians from all sectors of society have taken to the streets demanding an answer to Mirambeaursquos original question about what became of the Petrocaribe cash.This vast sum of over  billion is part of low-interest loans provided by Petrocaribe, a Venezuela-led oil-purchasing alliance of Caribbean states that since  was aimed at helping Haitirsquos ailing economy. The funds became crucial emergency money to the country following the devastating earthquake of  that laid waste to swathes of Port-au-Prince and beyond.Since then, the missing cash and whole Petrocaribe affair has become a political cause celebre in a country where ordinary people have seen a % hike in fuel prices and double-digit inflation that has made day-to-day survival extremely challenging for more than % of the population.For decades, ordinary Haitians have felt themselves powerless when confronted with this ongoing legacy of corruption and misgovernment. Presented with few alternative options, iniably they take to the streets as a last resort when trying to change things for the better.With so many locked in the grip of protracted poverty their frustration with the countryrsquos level of corruption is understandable. To take but one example following the  earthquake, it became clear that despite foreign donors pledging more than  billion in aid, less than % of that emergency aid spent in their names went directly to Haitians.I well recall in the wake of the earthquake talking to ordinary Haitians who had lost almost everything. One was a woman called Gladys Pierre, a mother who described that day back in  when just before five orsquoclock the mirrors fell from the walls in her family home and the furniture rose up and flew through the air asthrown by a giant malevolent poltergeist.ldquoA big beam slid, and from the chest up Rachelle was crushed against the wall like a mosquito, and I knew my little girl had died, Gladys told me, her voice trailing off.Unimaginable as the horror of her story was, it didnrsquot stop there. Steeling herself, she continued to tell of how her daughterrsquos semi-crushed skull became a grotesque prop for part of the apartment block wall that remained standing.In the following months, so dangerous were those ruins teetering on their macabre headstone that no-one dared enter to remove Rachellersquos corpse.Like many ordinary Haitians who found themselves now living in one of the tarpaulin cities that became semi-permanent fixtures in Port-au-Prince, Gladys and her husband Joel held out little hope of those in power doing much to improve their lives.ldquoYou only see them in their beautul cars and big jeeps driving up and down but they never stop, never get out of the car, talk to us or even congratulate the women and children on their courage, I recall Joel telling me at the time.And so, in the eyes of many Haitians, this sense of helplessness and frustration remains the way they see their lives and once again anger has boiled over in the country.While president Moise has pledged a crackdown on corruption few see little signs of it. Those who have taken to the streets as part of the protest movement in recent weeks have no clear political leader, but Haiti has a huge diaspora that has harnessed social media in its non-violent #PetroCaribeChallenge, campaigning among a population more than half of whom are under  years old.As ever, though, tensions have risen as government repression against the campaigners has become more unrestrained and brutal. Even in the early stages the signs of this were all too clear when last November armed gangs close to the ruling party, together with corrupt police officers, massacred at least  people just days before protests were due to begin.All this time, US influence ndash official or unofficial ndash has never been far from the surface in Haiti. In the latest case of murky US interference, five heavily-armed Americans were arrested in Port-au-Prince last week along with a Haitian man and two Serbians.The Americans are former Navy Seal officers Christopher Michael Osman and Christopher Mark McKinley, and Marine veteran Kent Leland Kroeker, as well as Talon Ray Burton and Dustin Porte. Burton is a private investigator once employed by the controversial private security company formerly known as Blackwater and the State Departmentrsquos diplomatic security service. Inside their vehicles the Haitian police found six automatic rles, six pistols, two professional drones and three satellite phones, and they were also carrying sets of licence plates.ldquoThey said that they were here on a lsquogovernment mission,rsquo ldquo Miami Herald reporter Jacqueline Charles told US National Public Radio. ldquoThey did not specy which government, but then they did tell the police that ... their boss was going to call their boss.Whether they were mercenaries, ldquogovernment contractors of something , the arrest of the Americans while failing to make global headlines triggered wide speculation about why they were in Haiti, particularly among Moisersquos political foes.The possible explanations range from a desire to protect the central bank or foreign assets to potential attacks on anti-government demonstrators and leaders. According to the Haitian police, the men claimed they were on a ldquogovernment mission when they were pulled over about a block away from the nationrsquos central bank.The US government only subsequently intervened after Haitian prime minister Jean Henry Ceant, speaking on CNN, called the group ldquomercenaries and ldquoterrorists. That they were released from prison and immediately flown back to Miami where they faced no charges has only further fuelled the rumour mill and caused political uproar in Haiti.Pierre Esperance, executive director of the National Human Rights Defence Network in Haiti, blasted the decision by US authorities not to charge the men.ldquoWhat the Haitian government did is grave. It shows that they had something they were looking for. The fact that the US took these people and did not charge them, it shows there was a conspiracy. They didnrsquot want them to go before Haitian justice, he told the Miami Herald.On Friday, the protests on the streets of Port-au-Prince showed no signs of abating. ldquoToday we lock down the country again, opposition leader Schiller Louidor told people who gathered for a funeral of two protesters killed earlier in the week, before they marched on the national palace carrying one of the coffins. ldquoWe are asking for justice. We are going to continue to protest. Jovenel Moise can kill as many people as he wants, he still has to go, said Josef Dicles, a cousin of one of the dead men, Onique Gedeus.And so Haiti is mired in turmoil again and just what the future holds is anybodyrsquos guess. But the mysterious presence of armed Americans and the cancellation of this monthrsquos scheduled carnival in Port-au-Prince certainly bodes ill for this long-suffering nation born out of slavery and still consigned to poverty.

title: chuka-umunna-urges-voters-to-join-movement-for-different-kind-of-politics
story: In a sign that The Independent Groupwill form a fully-fledged parliamentary party, the former Labour MP called for the public to ldquojoin us, and help us forge a new, dferent kind of politics for Britainrsquos future.Our political system is clearly completely broken. Lets change it#ChangePoliticsSIGN UP ## https:t.co NFfmnkIYSUBSCRIBE ## https:t.co TmbLEQp pic TXOTArNmdash Chuka UmunnaFebruary , Mr Umunna, who represents Streatham in south London, is one of eight ex-Labour MPs who have joined forces with three former Tories to form a new group in the Commons.TIG does not have a leader or a detailed policy , however an Opinium poll for The Observer has put the grouprsquos support at % ndash a point ahead of the Lib Dems.Opinium Observer latest political poll: LAB %CON % TIG %LD %  ndash  Febmdash OpiniumFebruary , Meanwhile it has emerged that Sir David Garrard, once one of Labourrsquos biggest donors, is supporting the new group.Writing in the Sunday Mirror, Mr Umunna said the current political system is not working and the established parties are ldquobroken.The former Labour frontbencher said the two main parties had become ldquodominated by extremes, citing factional infighting in his old party and the influence of hardline Brexiteers in the Tories.ldquoThis week we have come together in the national interest, to say lsquoenough is enoughrsquo. We have each put everything on the line to give something new a try. Believe me, it wasnrsquot an easy decision for any of us, Mr Umunna said.ldquoWe donrsquot yet know the destination where the path wersquove taken will lead us. But what me and my Independent Group colleagues are absolutely clear about is that we cannot and must not re-create the old parties with their tribalism and incompetence.ldquoAs we embark on this new chapter, most importantly we want you to help us build a new movement, and wersquore keen to hear from you. Join us, and help us forge a new, dferent kind of politics for Britainrsquos future.TIGrsquos MPs all campaigned for Britain to remain in the EU, while Mr Ummuna has been a prominent supporter of a so-called Peoplersquos Vote.The former shadow business secretary and Labour leadership contender has been described the ldquoobvious candidate to lead TIG in the Commons, where the -strong group equals the Lib Dems in size and outnumbers the DUP by one.There has been continued speculation that more Labour and Tory MPs will quit and potentially join the new group in the coming days and weeks as Brexit comes to a head.The departures already mark the biggest parliamentary schism since the formation of the Social Democratic Party in the s.However, many of TIGrsquos MPs will face a huge challengethey want to hold on to their seats in a future election.Tory breakaway Anna Soubry saw Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and several members of his shadow cabinet stage a rally in her Broxtowe constituency on Saturday.Thank you to everyone who came to our rally in Broxtowe ndash the seat Anna Soubry won by a tiny margin in .Were building a movement to win the next General Election and transform communities across the UK. pic qRzMREyeMUmdash Jeremy CorbynFebruary , Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry said MPs who left Labour had ldquobetrayed their seats and will be defeatedelections are held."Stand tall, stand firm, be proud. We are the future and they are the past. Our future is coming and its coming soon."My message to the brilliant rally in Broxstowe today #ForTheMany pic wbJAUwCrYmdash Emily ThornberryFebruary , Fighting for seats in a general election will require signicant funding, although TIG has already attracted support from major donors who have abandoned the main parties in recent months.Mr Umunna told The Times on Saturday that the group had already raised ldquotens of thousands of pounds from several thousand small donors.And on Sunday Sir David told The Observer: ldquoIrsquove been asked whether I will financially support the new group. I have already done so.The property tycoon, who donated around pound. million to Labour over a period of  years, left the party in protest at the leadershiprsquos handling of the anti-Semitism row.Pimlico Plumbers founder Charlie Mullins, who previously donated to the Tories and then the Lib Dems, indicated to The Times on Saturday that he could also give TIG financial backing.ldquoI believe that any money I put in to the Independent Group will be money well spent because I think Theresa May is destroying the economy, he said.ldquoThis is about our children and grandchildren and the future of this country.

title: tv-review-is-the-new-bbc-scotland-channel-magic-or-mince
story: Three, two, one went the countdown and there was Chvrches singer Lauren Mayberry singing a number which would not be out of place in the next Bond film. Programming proper began, oddly, with A Night at the Theatrehosted by Iain Stirling, the voice of Love Island, the ITV reality show infamous for the thickness of the contestants and the thinness of the sheets under which they have sex on camera.ChVrches and SSO open new channelIf you know who Stirling is then you are probably the target demographic of the new channel. If not, then you, like me, are part of the fuddy duddy majority, those who sit down to an eveningrsquos viewing as we would a meal, consuming one programme after another till wersquove had enough, or the wine runs out. The Love Island lot are the take away set, snacking on ldquocontent" whenever and wherever they choose, either on social media or iPlayer.Whatever your age, the only thing worse than A Night at the Theatre would have been an afternoon in surgery. Tired, unfunny and peppered with audience participation games, it made The Good Old Days look like Sinatra at the Sands.STV, which closed down last year after failing to attract enough viewers, was run on pound million a year, bawbees in TV terms. BBC Scotland has pound million, but from that sum, which would buy three and a bit hours of Netflixrsquos The Crown, it has to fund  hours of programmes. Getting Hitched Asian Stylegave a hint of how the new channel would make the pennies stretch. A documentary about wedding planners Saffron Events, it had good talkersand some mild drama , but it was baggy and repetitive, just about it making it to an hourrsquos worth of material. There are two more parts to come. Is there really more to say YouTube star on new seriesThe Peoplersquos Newsgave people the chance to, er, give us their views on the news. There was one official taxi driver on it, and lots of people who could have been taxi drivers so in love were they with the sound of their own voices. A little bit Gogglebox, and accompanied by a head-splitting soundtrack, the hipsters at Channel  news will be kicking themselves they did not think of this first.At last, a proper event for event TV: the first episode of the final series of Still Game . With the dreadful timing of the Scotland football squad, the gang have found their form again when it no longer matters. The story about Jack and Victor entering the YouTube age was about as original as jokes about cat videos, but it left plenty of room for what SG does best: daftness laced with cyanide-strength sarcasm Burnistoun Tunes Inwas patchy, but some of the old stuff still works a treat. The nightrsquos final offering was the brilliant documentary Nae Pasaran , about a boycott by Scots engineers that curbed Pinochetrsquos bombing of his own people. Running it earlier would have given the channel a stamp of quality and seriousness, which it needed.Tutti Frutti is backLast night was supposed to be about the thrill of the new,there is such a thing any more in a multichannel world, yet there was something familiar about the evening. It took a while to pin down, then it came to me. The widely-trailedof favourite shows that inevitably struggled to live up to expectations, lots of familiar faces, a whf of prissiness. Yes, it was Hogmanay TV, but on a Sunday in February. BBC Scotland director Donalda MacKinnon has said the channelrsquos goal is "success over time". Consider the clock ticking.

title: prime-minister-aims-to-push-ahead-with-domestic-agenda-once-uk-has-left-eu
story: The Prime Minister insisted her job was not only about delivering Brexit on the scheduled date of March , but also dealing with issues like the NHS.Mrs May stressed that, once the UK had formally withdrawn from the EU, a new future partnership deal with the bloc needed to be hammered out.The PMs comments come after she made it clear to Tory MPs in December that she would not lead the party into the next scheduled General Election in .That move was thought to have helped Mrs May survive a vote of no confidence in her leadership before Christmas.Her remarks also follow reports that some ministers want her to quit after the May local elections.Referencing her pledge to create a fairer society when she first entered Downing Street, Mrs May said: "I was very clear in December with the Conservative Party that as far as Im concerned, what I am doing, my job is not only about delivering Brexit, actually theres a domestic agenda that I am delivering on."It reflects what I said on the doorstep of Number Ten when I first became Prime Minister."Thats why weve been making key decisions like the extra money for the National Health Service, the long-term plan for the National Health Service, and there is still a domestic agenda that I want to get on with."The PMs victory in the confidence vote means that she cannot face another such attempt to oust her until the end of this year.Mrs May said that, after withdrawal, the UK still needed to agree its future relations with Brussels.Speaking as she attended an EU-League of Arab States summit in Egypt, the PM added: "Theres a second part of the negotiations in terms of the future economic partnership, the future security partnership."We have set out a clear framework for that in the Political Declaration. Thats the basis on which those negotiations would go forward."The complete package of Brexit, we leave on March , but also we have to put in place that future relationship because thats about the sustainable long-term relationship of the UK with the EU."

title: umunna-sets-sights-on-tig-leadership-as-labour-and-tories-braced-for-more-defections
story: Today, TIG, as it has become known, prepares to hold its inaugural meeting and, as it does so, the leaderships of the Labour and Conservative parties are bracing themselves for more defections.Mr Umunna, who represents Streatham in London, is one of eight ex-Labour MPs who have joined forces with three former Tories to create the new centrist force in the Commons.Askedhe was going to be TIGrsquos leader, the -year-old politician told Sky News Sophy Ridge on Sunday: "Im clear I want to play the biggest role in this group and one of the things about the way we operate is the recognition that were all leaders."Mr Umunnas comments came as his former colleague Barry Gardiner, the Shadow International Trade Secretary, accused him of quitting Labour to join TIG because he knew he could never become leader of his former party."It was fairly clear to me the reason he wanted to leave the Labour Party was that he knew he could never lead the Labour Party," Mr Gardiner told the same programme. "This is about personality."Mr Ummuna has claimed the current party system is "broken" and has spoken in favour of proportional representation.He added: "Were quite clear that we believe that we should have the closest possible relationship with the European Union because were internationalists."We believe that the inidual should be given a  to succeed, that we have inidual responsibilities ourselves and people dont want their lives to be run by the state, that they would support education, infrastructure and the health service but also we believe, ultimately, that work is an incredibly important value and we need to give people a level of security that they expect."Now none of the established parties are providing the answers to those challenges."The former Shadow Business Secretary continued: "If within our group we are capable of forming a consensus around policies when we get to that point, then we have a much better chance of coming up with something that can unite our ided nation."Mr Umunna claimed Labour had become ldquounbearable and, commenting on anti-Semitism within the party, said: "I blame Jeremy Corbyn but I also blame other people who have acted as bystanders."It is disgraceful that the Shadow Cabinet has not done more, not been more vocal, not demanded more, not threatened to resign over what has been going on over anti-Semitism and the problem is, its too easy to choose an easy le because there is a rule by fear."Meanwhile, his TIG colleague Heidi Allen, a former Conservative MP, speaking about the roll-out of the Governments flagship new benefits system Universal Credit, told BBC Ones The Andrew Marr Show: "It could be the most phenomenal benefit system out there but, at the moment, its treating people not like human beings, just like a sausage machine."Askedthe group would become a political party, the Cambridgeshire MP replied: "Yes, thats the hope, absolutely."**Responding to an assertion over the weekend by Emily Thornberry that TIG should be crushed, TIG MP Luciana Berger said such comments led her to believe she had made the right decision to quit Labour.ldquoActually, thats the culture of a politics that Im leaving behind, declared the Liverpool MP, adding: ldquoWe should be operating in an open way, in a tolerant way, that that is what in the st century the country deserves."

title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. The answer to this all depends on whether we leave the EU with or without a deal and when you want to travel.Pet passports wont be valid with a no deal BrexitAt the minute, you are supposed to have a pet passport for your dogtheyrsquore travelling from the UK to the EU and vice versa, although it is my understanding that there are no checks on pets crossing the Republic or Ireland and Northern Ireland border at the minute. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. Your dog will need a rabies vaccine with blood samplestaken  days after the jab. title: embroidery exhibition at heritage centre
story: The Garioch Heritage Centre in Inverurie will host the Embroiderer#s Guild Lest We Forget embroidery exhibition next week.The free exhibition will run at the centre from Tuesday, February  to Tuesday, March .In  the Guild in conjunction with SSAFAinvited its members to take part in the commemoration of the ending of WW a  years previously by producing one heart.The plan being that each heart would be included in at least one exhibition, ideally, as near to their home location.Thus making unique and thoughtful exhibitions to fulfil the hope of a generation not to be forgotten.Using cloth, thread and textile each heart interprets a unique story of comradeship, bravery, victory or setback told by those ing from the Great War or in their heartfelt letters to those back home.The hearts illustrate to a new generation the men and the animals that accompanied them the unorms worn and medals won the regiments that fought together and the family members fondly remembered the songs that kept their spirits high and the words they wrote to those back home. title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: accessibility top of the agenda for northlink
story: Changes are being made by NorthLink Ferries to make their services more accessible to all.On board information workshops and the introduction of new website software are the latest efforts being made by the company to improve services for those with additional support needs.The ferry operator implemented its new Recite Me accessibility tool on its website, this month, to make it more suitable to folk#s needs. The new software — which can be used on desktops and mobile browsers — allows website visitors to customise what they see and hear, from changing the contrast settings, language, font size and more.In the UK, there are estimated to be . million people with a learning disability and . million people who have English as a second language. ‘Recite Me’ has the ability to translate the NorthLink Ferries website into more than  languages — including Scots Gaelic . It can also translate text-to-speech to help visually impaired users and focus screen areas for those with dyslexia.On Monday, February , teams on board MV Hamnavoe hosted an Access Panel Orkney session, where staff were provided with disability awareness training. During the two-hour session, staff were able to experience what it’s like to have a disability by wearing glasses that simulated blindness, used wheelchairs and crutches and had their hearing dampened.Carolyn Grfiths of Access Panel Orkney said: “The aim of our session was to let staff experience disabilities first-hand so they can empathise with passengers’ needs.#All of us running the training have a disability so we were able to provide first-hand examples of what accessible travel is like for us. We were delighted to be welcomed on board to provide this training and it’s great to see a company like Serco NorthLink Ferries take accessibility for passengers seriously.”The MV Hjaltland will also host a Making Connections workshop today, Friday, February . The workshop will look at how passengers navigate potential barriers when changing from one mode of transport to another. Making Connections brings disabled people together with transport operators to discuss, address and plan how travel connections can be made easier.Seumas Campbell, customer service director at NorthLink Ferries, said: “Catering for passengers with ying degrees of disability is an important part of our service provision. Whether they are using our website to book their journey, making a connection from other forms of public transport or coming on board one of our vessels, we believe that passengers should experience a service that caters to all their needs.“The new website software will allow visitors to customise what they see and hear and as more and more visitors from around the world choose NorthLink Ferries to travel to the Northern Isles, ‘Recite Me’ is a great tool to help them plan and book their journey.“Our workshops are also a great way in training our staff on how they can best help and understand passengers’ needs. We pride ourselves on having a great team that always provides the best service so it’s important that we’re constantly refreshing their training.”For more information on accessibility for passengers on NorthLink Ferries, you can visit www.northlinkferries copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: council issues kirkyards apology
story: Orkney Islands Council has made an official apology following public concern about the way the county#s kirkyards are being managed.Distraught families and dismayed public officials have spoken out in recent weeks, after a scheme to improve the safety of cemeteries triggered reports that headstones were being laid flat without relatives being notied.Last week, a council insider told The Orcadian that — in failing to contact families — the council was disregarding government guidelines on cemetery maintenance.“It says it’s good practice to inform the families and give them an opportunity to repair the memorial, and that’s just not being done at all,” the inside source said.The Orcadian also heard from Stewart Spence, whose father#s headstone had been laid down in the Sandwick kirkyard with no notication from the council. This was despite the fact that the name and address of the person they needed to contact — his mother Edna — was engraved on the memorial.#Vandals couldn#t have done a better job,# he said.Following this wave of public concern, OIC convener Harvey Johnston and chief executive Alistair Buchan have now released a statement apologising for the concern and upset that this project has caused.#Following a tragic accident involving a young child at a Glasgow cemetery, the Scottish Government asked councils to carry out detailed inspections in the interests of public safety,# they said.#We therefore engaged in the kirkyard safety programme for all the right reasons, but recognise that the process we have followed needs to be improved. It was never envisaged that the resulting work would leave kirkyards in the condition they are in. We are sorry about the concern and upset this has led to.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect. We will also consider how best to contact and discuss the remedial work required with those concerned. People’s safety is an important concern for us and we will continue to carry out headstone inspections. As at Warebeth , we will use blue pegs to mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives.#These stones will not be touched until we publicise the inspection results and give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.#The statement also confirmed that further updates from the council will be provided further updates over the weeks ahead.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: german fleet salvage sites archaeology project results published online
story: With the centenary of the scuttling of the German High Seas Fleet in Scapa Flow fast approaching in June of this year, a fascinating insight into remains of aspects of the wrecks has now been published online.Historic Environment Scotland commissioned the Orkney Research Centre for Archaeology and SULA Diving to complete a full survey of the wrecks and debris remaining on the sea bed following the inter-war salvage operations.The seven remaining ships of the High Seas Fleet have seen Scapa Flow become one of the most well-known e sites in the World. Those wrecks are still the primary focus of recreational ers, but the remains of the vessels that were mostly recovered and removed from Scapa Flow have also been a recognised ing resource for many years.However, the exact extent and composition of these so-called salvage sites was unknown until this week, when the report of the second phase of work on these sites was published online.The overall aim of the Scapa Flow Salvage Sites Project was to determine what remains of the many vessels of the German High Seas Fleet that were salvaged in the years that followed their scuttling in June .Phase One, undertaken over the winter of  , involved a side scan sonar survey of the main anchorages and other areas thought to have been involved in the salvage process.In the second phase of this project, ers and remotely operated vehicles examined and recorded the remains in detail.The overall result is that the vast majority of salvage sites in Scapa Flow have been located and the remains at each site have been directly investigated and recorded.The full report is now available for public download through the Scapa Flow Historic Wreck website http:www.scapaflowwrecks projects salvage-sites-phase- Further details in The Orcadian on Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons — Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat — also known as Repulse Bay — in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism — findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians — adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur welcomes fuel poverty re think
story: Orkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur has welcomed Scottish Government plans to ensure that its Fuel Poverty Bill recognises the higher costs faced by those living in remote rural and island areas.During the stage one debate in Parliament yesterday, Wednesday, the Housing Minister, Kevin Stewart indicated that he would bring forward amendments to the bill to include an ‘uplt’ to the minimum income standard for rural and island communities. Mr McArthur believes this reflects a change in approach by the government, after months of campaigning by the Orkney MSP and a range of organisations involved in tackling fuel poverty across the Highlands and Islands.During his remarks, Mr McArthur pointed out that when it comes to fuel poverty, rural and island areas are disproportionately affected, with Orkney having the highest proportion of households in fuel poverty and extreme fuel poverty anywhere in Scotland.Commenting after the debate, Mr McArthur said: “Fuel poverty blights communities across Scotland, but there is no doubt that it has a disproportionate impact on rural and island areas. Until recently, however, the Scottish Government appeared unwilling to recognise this fact or indeed the higher costs faced by those living in our rural and island communities.“Over recent months, working with a range of organisations with a wealth of experience and expertise in tackling fuel poverty, I have made the case for the Minister, Kevin Stewart to think again.  It was a case that the Local Government Committee was also persuaded to support.“I am delighted, therefore, that the Minister has had a change of heart and committed to bring forward amendments to his bill at stage two that better reflect the specic nature of fuel poverty in places like Orkney.  I look forward to seeing the detail of those amendments and will work with Mr Stewart, and local stakeholders in Orkney, to make sure we get this right.“Given the impact fuel poverty can have, not just on people’s quality of le but their physical and mental health, this bill has the potential to make a real dference.  For that to happen, it must be both effective and ambitious in eradicating fuel poverty from communities across the country.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
